    <script nonce="XOPkNg6M296qOYvPQapX5wEjo0cP5MLyGqrq4wUnk/kUCUN7">
      window.SDK_PLATFORM = "browser";
      // @TODO [APPSDK-667] Remove this once the desktop platform APIs are exposed
      window.APP_VERSION = "11.18.0-241015-0634";
      window.BASE_URL_PREFIX =  "/build";
      window.WEBSOCKET_URL = "https://bifrost-web-v4.gw.postman.co";
      window.HTTP_GATEWAY_URL = "https://bifrost-web-https-v4.gw.postman.co";
      window.IS_PUBLIC_DOMAIN = "false" === 'true';
      window.USER_ID =  "39106045";
      window.TEAM_ID =  "0";
      window.USER_LOCALE =  "en-US" || 'en-US';
      window.EXTERNAL_ID = "39106045";
      window.RELEASE_CHANNEL = "prod";
      // this evaluates to true if the feature flag is enabled
      window.v2RoutesPublisherEnabled =  "false" === 'true';

      /**
       * Creating an IIFE, to create local variables inside defined scope, and
       * not in the global scope
       */
      (() => {
        const isBrowser = "browser" === 'browser';
        const userId = new URL(location.href).searchParams.get('userId');
        globalThis.__WP_IS_SIGNED_OUT_DESKTOP__ = !isBrowser && (!userId || userId === '0');
      })();
    </script>

    

    <script nonce="XOPkNg6M296qOYvPQapX5wEjo0cP5MLyGqrq4wUnk/kUCUN7">
      let route = window.location.pathname;
      function injectHomePageChunk() {
        // Route based chunk injection for home page
        // This is a temporary solution
        // There is a more comprehensive solution in the works to make artemis-service route aware
        let assetsUrl = "/_ar-assets";
        if ((route === '/home' || route === '/') && window.USER_ID === '0') {
          let homePageChunk = "";
          let synchronousScript = document.createElement('script');

          // Set and append synchronous script
          synchronousScript.setAttribute('src', `${assetsUrl}/${homePageChunk}.js`);
          document.head.appendChild(synchronousScript);
        }
      }
    </script>

    <!-- preload script -->
    

    <script type="text/javascript" nonce="XOPkNg6M296qOYvPQapX5wEjo0cP5MLyGqrq4wUnk/kUCUN7">
      const urlParts = window.location.pathname ? window.location.pathname.split('/') : [];
      const workspaceLabelIndex = urlParts.length > 0 ? urlParts.indexOf('workspace') : -1;
      const workspaceSlug = workspaceLabelIndex > -1 ? urlParts[workspaceLabelIndex + 1] : '';
      const workspaceId = workspaceSlug ? workspaceSlug.split('~')[1] : undefined;
      const requestIndex = urlParts ? urlParts.indexOf('request') : null;
      window.preFetchMeta = {};


      let requestId = requestIndex !== -1 && urlParts.length > requestIndex + 1 ? urlParts[requestIndex + 1] : null;

      // strip any query params from the request id
      if (requestId && requestId.includes('?')) {
        requestId = requestId.split('?')[0];
      }

      // Unsaved request should not be prefetched
      if (requestId === 'create') {
        requestId = null;
      }

      let HOST = window.HTTP_GATEWAY_URL;

      if (window.RELEASE_CHANNEL !== 'dev' && HOST) {
        // CDN understands the _api prefix and routes to Bifrost by omitting it
        // _api helps us isolate the API namespace from real-world use cases
        HOST = `${window.location.origin}/_api`;
      }


      if (!workspaceId || !window.HTTP_GATEWAY_URL) {
        window.collectionSidebarListCachedResponse = null;
        window.initialWorkspaceSettingsPromise = null;
        window.fetchActiveEditorCollection = null;

        window.preFetchMeta = {
          allPreFetchesFailed: true,
          allPreFetchesFailedMessage: `Invalid workspace id: workspaceId: ${workspaceId}, HTTP_GATEWAY_URL: ${window.HTTP_GATEWAY_URL}`,
          lastWindowPath: window.location.pathname
        };
      }

      else {
        async function fetchCollectionSidebarList() {
          try {
            performance.mark('collection-sidebar-list-prefetch-network-start');

            const collectionSidebarListCached = await fetch(`${HOST}/list/collection?workspace=${workspaceId}`, {
              method: 'POST',
              headers: {
                'x-app-version': window.APP_VERSION,
                'x-entity-team-id': window.TEAM_ID
              },
              credentials: 'include'
            })
            .then(async (response) => {
              if (!response || response.status !== 200) {
                throw new Error(`Failed to fetch collection sidebar list with status ${response.status}`);
              }

              const jsonList = await response.json();

              console.log('Collection sidebar list successfully pre fetched');

              return jsonList;
            })
            .catch((error) => {
              console.warn('Failed to fetch collection sidebar list', error);

              throw error;
            })
            .finally(() => {
              performance.mark('collection-sidebar-list-prefetch-network-end');
            });

            return collectionSidebarListCached;
          }
          catch (error) {
            window.preFetchMeta = {
              ...window.preFetchMeta,
              fetchCollectionSidebarListFailed: true,
              fetchCollectionSidebarListFailedMessage: `Failed to fetch collection sidebar list with error: ${error}`
            };

            console.warn('Error occurred while fetching sidebar', error);
          }
        }

        async function fetchActiveEditorCollection () {
          // bail out if requestId is not available
          if (!requestId || !HOST) {
            console.warn('Collection sync pre fetch bailed out.', requestId, HOST);
            return;
          }

          performance.mark('collection-sync-prefetch-network-start');

          window.prefetchedActiveEditorRequest = { id: requestId };

          const prefetchedActiveEditorCollection = await fetch(`${HOST}/collection/sync?since_id=0&favorite=true&exclude=response%2Crequest&request=${requestId}`, {
            method: 'GET',
            headers: {
              'x-app-version': window.APP_VERSION,
              'x-entity-team-id': window.TEAM_ID
            },
            credentials: 'include'
          })
          .then(async (response) => {
            if (!response || response.status !== 200) {
              console.warn('Failed to pre fetch active editor collection', response);

              throw new Error(`Failed to pre fetch active editor collection with status ${response.status}`);
            }

            const jsonResponse = await response.json();

            try {
              window.prefetchedActiveEditorRequest.collection = `${jsonResponse.entities[0].data.owner}-${jsonResponse.entities[0].data.id}`;
            } catch (err) {
              console.warn('Prefetched collections\'s id not found', err);

              throw new Error('Invalid collection id');
            }

            return { body: jsonResponse };
          })
          .catch((err) => {
            console.warn('Failed to pre fetch active editor collection', err);

            window.prefetchedActiveEditorRequest = null;

            window.preFetchMeta = {
              ...window.preFetchMeta,
              fetchActiveEditorCollectionFailed: true,
              fetchActiveEditorCollectionFailedMessage: `Failed to fetch active editor collection with error: ${err}`
            };

            throw new Error('Failed to pre fetch active editor collection');
          })
          .finally(() => {
            performance.mark('collection-sync-prefetch-network-end');
          });

          return prefetchedActiveEditorCollection;
        }

        // Call the function to fetch data and store it
        // we are not waiting for the promise to resolve and should happen async
        window.collectionSidebarListCachedResponse = fetchCollectionSidebarList();
        window.fetchActiveEditorCollection = fetchActiveEditorCollection();
    }
    </script>

    <script nonce="XOPkNg6M296qOYvPQapX5wEjo0cP5MLyGqrq4wUnk/kUCUN7">
      try {
        const localeAssets = JSON.parse('{"localeManifest":["locale-asset-manifest-11-18-0-241015-0634.json"],"en-US":{"preload":["/locales/en-US/global-core-3cd29a4c87d58e35.json","/locales/en-US/app-header-6e75e0d619d78c1a.json"],"prefetch":["/locales/en-US/settings-c082e99a05ba65f4.json","/locales/en-US/team-profile-settings-71bf2ab6dfe32331.json","/locales/en-US/team-settings-5d2b482ac22a42fe.json"],"workspacePreload":["/locales/en-US/workbench-core-ec74a90c7b39696b.json","/locales/en-US/workspace-sidebar-core-a945f8c45af14ce7.json"]},"ja":{"preload":["/locales/ja/global-core-252c2c01df4959ab.json","/locales/ja/app-header-9dbed4551124c248.json"],"prefetch":["/locales/ja/settings-4724b6eb0edf6a50.json","/locales/ja/team-profile-settings-29f6886400274032.json","/locales/ja/team-settings-79c79b7edc837576.json"],"workspacePreload":["/locales/ja/workbench-core-2f55b260698334eb.json","/locales/ja/workspace-sidebar-core-9429e81f23c57d9a.json"]}}');
        const assetsUrl = "/_ar-assets";
        const nonce = "XOPkNg6M296qOYvPQapX5wEjo0cP5MLyGqrq4wUnk/kUCUN7";
        const isWorkspacePage = route.includes('workspace/');
        const languageSpecificAssets = localeAssets[window.USER_LOCALE];
        for (let group in languageSpecificAssets) {
          for (let asset of languageSpecificAssets[group]) {
            let localeManifestLink = document.createElement('link');
            let relAttr;
            switch (group) {
              case 'workspacePreload':
                relAttr = isWorkspacePage ? 'preload' : 'prefetch';
                break;
              default:
                relAttr = group || 'prefetch';
                break;
            }
            localeManifestLink.setAttribute('rel', relAttr);
            localeManifestLink.setAttribute('as', 'fetch');
            localeManifestLink.setAttribute('href', `${assetsUrl}${asset}`);
            localeManifestLink.setAttribute('nonce', nonce);
            localeManifestLink.setAttribute('crossorigin', 'anonymous');
            localeManifestLink.setAttribute('type', 'application/json');
            document.head.appendChild(localeManifestLink);
          }
        }
      } catch (e) {}
    </script>

    <script nonce="XOPkNg6M296qOYvPQapX5wEjo0cP5MLyGqrq4wUnk/kUCUN7">
      try {
        const settingsKey = Object.keys(localStorage).filter(item => item.includes('settings'))[0];
        // get system theme
        const systemTheme = window.matchMedia('(prefers-color-scheme: dark)')?.matches ? 'dark': 'light';
        const themeChunks = JSON.parse('["THEME_DRACULA-b95412c34599e716.min.js","THEME_MONOKAI-d141b8bdb725af95.min.js","THEME_AYU_LIGHT-a467b39e3e22634d.min.js","THEME_AYU_DARK-cf95de5f68747704.min.js","THEME_HIGH_CONTRAST_LIGHT-510f04195793b273.min.js","THEME_HIGH_CONTRAST_DARK-2d4ebcb69c4bdcee.min.js","THEME_NIGHT_OWL_LIGHT-2547259d0c1345b9.min.js","THEME_NIGHT_OWL_DARK-c5bab263c0c54dbb.min.js","THEME_SOLARIZED_LIGHT-daa1197ed9808c8f.min.js","THEME_SOLARIZED_DARK-32d87a86cc188231.min.js","THEME_DRACULA-b95412c34599e716.min.js.map","THEME_MONOKAI-d141b8bdb725af95.min.js.map","THEME_AYU_LIGHT-a467b39e3e22634d.min.js.map","THEME_AYU_DARK-cf95de5f68747704.min.js.map","THEME_HIGH_CONTRAST_LIGHT-510f04195793b273.min.js.map","THEME_HIGH_CONTRAST_DARK-2d4ebcb69c4bdcee.min.js.map","THEME_NIGHT_OWL_LIGHT-2547259d0c1345b9.min.js.map","THEME_NIGHT_OWL_DARK-c5bab263c0c54dbb.min.js.map","THEME_SOLARIZED_LIGHT-daa1197ed9808c8f.min.js.map","THEME_SOLARIZED_DARK-32d87a86cc188231.min.js.map"]');
        const assetsUrl = "/_ar-assets";
        const nonce = "XOPkNg6M296qOYvPQapX5wEjo0cP5MLyGqrq4wUnk/kUCUN7";
        let themeToPaint;

        if (settingsKey) {
          // check theme from storage, if it exists
          const currentTheme = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem(settingsKey))?.postmanTheme;
          // check system theme sync setting
          const isSystemThemeActive = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem('settings'))?.shouldUseSystemTheme;

          if (currentTheme) {
            themeToPaint = isSystemThemeActive ? systemTheme : currentTheme;
          }
          else {
            themeToPaint = systemTheme;
          }
        }
        else {
            themeToPaint = systemTheme;
        }

        const asset = themeChunks.find((value) => value.toLowerCase().replaceAll('_', '-').indexOf(themeToPaint) >= 0);
        let headerBgColor = ''; // dark theme: grey-90 | light theme: grey-00
        let headerSkeletonColor = ''; // dark theme: grey-85 | light theme: grey-10
        let headerBorderColor = ''; // dark theme: grey-70 | light theme: grey-20
        let spinnerBgColor = ''; // dark theme: grey-50 | light theme: grey-40

        if (!['dark', 'light'].includes(themeToPaint) && asset) {
          const link = document.createElement('link');

          link.setAttribute('rel', 'preload');
          link.setAttribute('as', 'script');
          link.setAttribute('href', `${assetsUrl}/${asset}`);
          link.setAttribute('nonce', nonce);

          document.head.appendChild(link);
        }

        switch (themeToPaint) {
          case 'dark':
            headerBgColor = '#212121';
            headerSkeletonColor = '#333333';
            headerBorderColor = '#404040';
            spinnerBgColor = '#6B6B6B';
            break;
          case 'dracula':
            headerBgColor = '#282A36';
            headerSkeletonColor = '#2E303E';
            headerBorderColor = '#43465B';
            spinnerBgColor = '#7E82A0';
            break;
          case 'monokai':
            headerBgColor = '#282923';
            headerSkeletonColor = '#30322A';
            headerBorderColor = '#484A3F';
            spinnerBgColor = '#8A8E7B';
            break;
          case 'ayu-light':
            headerBgColor = '#F8F9FA';
            headerSkeletonColor = '#E5E9F0';
            headerBorderColor = '#D8DDE8';
            spinnerBgColor = '#8293B5';
            break;
          case 'ayu-dark':
            headerBgColor = '#0D1016';
            headerSkeletonColor = '#151A23';
            headerBorderColor = '#2D384D';
            spinnerBgColor = '#5C729D';
            break;
          case 'high-contrast-light':
            headerBgColor = '#FFFFFF';
            headerSkeletonColor = '#F2F2F2';
            headerBorderColor = '#EDEDED';
            spinnerBgColor = '#A6A6A6';
            break;
          case 'high-contrast-dark':
            headerBgColor = '#0D0D0D';
            headerSkeletonColor = '#161616';
            headerBorderColor = '#454545';
            spinnerBgColor = '#7D7D7D';
            break;
          case 'night-owl-light':
            headerBgColor = '#FBFBFB';
            headerSkeletonColor = '#F0F0F0';
            headerBorderColor = '#DBDBDB';
            spinnerBgColor = '#5D7F9C';
            break;
          case 'night-owl-dark':
            headerBgColor = '#011727';
            headerSkeletonColor = '#092339';
            headerBorderColor = '#134977';
            spinnerBgColor = '#5D7F9C';
            break;
          case 'solarized-light':
            headerBgColor = '#FCF6E5';
            headerSkeletonColor = '#EBE5D1';
            headerBorderColor = '#CFC9B5';
            spinnerBgColor = '#ABA592';
            break;
          case 'solarized-dark':
            headerBgColor = '#002B36';
            headerSkeletonColor = '#073642';
            headerBorderColor = '#274C57';
            spinnerBgColor = '#657B83';
            break;
          default:
            headerBgColor = '#212121';
            headerSkeletonColor = '#333333';
            headerBorderColor = '#404040';
            spinnerBgColor = '#6B6B6B';
        }

        if (themeToPaint && themeToPaint !== 'light') {
          const cssRule = `.requester-shell-loader-main-header, .pm-loader { background-color: ${headerBgColor}; } .requester-shell-loader-main-header { box-shadow: inset 0 -1px 0 ${headerBorderColor};} .item-tabs, .requester-shell-loader-searchbox, .item-circle, .item-rectangle { background-color: ${headerSkeletonColor}; } .aether-spinner > div { background-color: ${spinnerBgColor}; };`;
          const styleTag = document.createElement('style');
          document.head.appendChild(styleTag);
          styleTag.type = 'text/css';
          styleTag.appendChild(document.createTextNode(cssRule));
        }
      } catch (e) { }
    </script>
  </head>

      /**
       * activate eager fetched requester-legacy.css on non-optimized pages
      */
      let elem = document.getElementById("requester-styles"),
        isOptimizedPages = ((route === '/home' || route === '/') && (window.USER_ID === '0' || window.USER_ID === '')) || (route === '/explore' || route.startsWith('/explore/')) || (route === '/onboarding/user');

      if (!isOptimizedPages) {
        elem.setAttribute("rel", "stylesheet");
        elem.setAttribute("type", "text/css");
      }

      try {
        window.pm = window.pm || {};

        let preloadCacheDiv = document.getElementById('postman_preload_cache')
            preloadCache = preloadCacheDiv && preloadCacheDiv.getAttribute('data-preload-cache');

        window.pm.preloadCache = preloadCache ? JSON.parse(preloadCache) : {};
      }
      catch (e) {
        console.warn('Error while parsing preload cache', e);

        window.pm = window.pm || {};
        window.pm.preloadCache = {};
      }

They follow a stateless client-server model, where server resources are represented as URLs, and interactions are performed through requests and responses. REST APIs are widely used in web development to create scalable and flexible systems.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What does the REST API basics template contain?","description":"\"The template contains:\\n\\n- A customizable collection with requests for a CRUD operation\\n\\n\\n- Test scripts for each request\\n\\n\\n- A base URL variable\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"How to use the REST API basics template?","description":"\"Think of the template as a hands-on tutorial for learning basics by interacting with a sample REST API.<br><br> It provides a customizable collection of requests for CRUD operations (Create, Read, Update, Delete). Open each request and click \"Send\" to see what happens.\n\n#### **Step 2: View responses**\n\nObserve the response tab for status code (200 OK), response time, and size.\n\n#### **Step 3: Send new Body data**\n\nUpdate or add new data in \"Body\" in the POST request. Typically, Body data is also used in PUT request.\n\n```\n{\n    \"name\": \"Add your name in the body\"\n}\n\n ```\n\n#### **Step 4: Update the variable**\n\nVariables enable you to store and reuse values in Postman. Replace it with your API endpoint to customize this collection.\n\n#### **Step 5: Add tests in the \"Scripts\" tab**\n\nAdding tests to your requests can help you confirm that your API is working as expected. neatly organized asset library.","keywords":"Reference documentation template"},"bannerHeader":"Explore how to help your fellow backend developers get started with your API faster"},"transactionId":null,"suggested":true,"recommended":true,"icon":"integration-testing-icon","collectionDescription":"> Reference Documentation is a catalog of all your predefined API components—requests, documentation, authorization, variables, and examples—into an organized asset library for faster onboarding of new team members. \n  \n\n### **Table of contents:**\n\n> 🪐 Get Started  \n📢 Recent Updates  \n🔐 Authorization  \n⏱ Rate and usage limits  \n✍️ Example Responses  \n🤔 Need Help? \n  \n\n## 🪐 **Get Started**\n\nSteps to get started with the Intergalactic Bank API:\n\n1. **Authorization**: Use a valid API Key to send requests to the API endpoints. For this API, everyone will use a temporary API key (prefilled as a collection variable).\n    \n2. **Access**: If you need elevated access to perform actions like creating new accounts, contact the Intergalactic Bank API product owner.\n    \n\n> Some endpoints are for Admin Users only. These are noted in the request's documentation. \n  \n\nFor more details, check out the additional sections below, and click `View Complete Documentation` for the complete documentation. If you have questions about the folder or request, look for the documentation icon for documentation-in-context.\n\n## 📢 Recent Updates\n\n<u>February 2024</u>\n\n- Added optional `createdAt` parameter to `List Transactions` endpoint to filter for transactions created on or after a given date.\n    \n\n<u>January 2024</u>\n\n- We're live! 🎉 The Intergalactic Bank API is now out of beta and available for our internal users. \"Watch\" this collection by clicking the 👁️ icon to be alerted to new updates.\n    \n\n## 🔐 Authorization\n\n- The Intergalactic Bank API uses an API Key for authorization.\n    \n- You must include an API key in each request to the Postman API with the `x-api-key` request header.\n    \n- The API key has been pre-filled as a [collection variable](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/variables/). The authorization has been set up at the collection level, so all requests in this collection will automatically inherit the needed header.\n    \n\n> ⚠ Don’t leak your secrets! Initial values are saved, and can be shared with others in team workspaces. Current values are local values that are not saved, and won't be persisted in the original shared collection, environment, or globals. [Learn more about variables in Postman](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/variables/#initial-and-current-values) \n  \n\n<img src=\"https://content.pstmn.io/bba75cfc-45c4-409e-9b1d-d604cbdf51a2/UmVmZXJlbmNlIHZhcmlhYmxlcy5naWY=\" width=\"486\" height=\"297\">\n\n## Rate and usage limits\n\nAPI access rate limits apply at a per-API key basis in unit time. The limit is 300 requests per minute.\n\nIf you exceed either limit, your request will return an HTTP `429 Too Many Requests` status code. If your team is consistently hitting these limits, contact the Intergalactic API Product Owner, and we will work to accommodate you.\n\nEach API response returns the following set of headers to help you identify your use status:\n\n| Header | Description |\n| --- | --- |\n| `X-RateLimit-Limit` | The maximum number of requests that the consumer is permitted to make per minute. |\n| `X-RateLimit-Remaining` | The number of requests remaining in the current rate limit window. |\n| `X-RateLimit-Reset` | The time at which the current rate limit window resets in UTC epoch seconds. |\n\n## ✍️ Example Responses\n\nWe have documented many of the possible responses you might encounter using [Examples](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/examples/) under each request.\n\n### 🤔 **Need Help?**\n\nThe Bank Services team wants to ensure that your team has everything they need to successfully integrate our services into your applications and services. Don't hesitate to reach out to us on our internal Slack by tagging `@bank-services`.\n\n> Is your team utilizing this API in a use case not represented here? We want to know about it! Add a comment with your suggestions and feedback! \n  \n\nFor ideas on how to use these different requests to accomplish common banking tasks, check out the [Workflows Documentation](https://www.postman.com/templates/53736124-ad4d-4cc9-a57a-f7e83402fbe7/Workflow-Documentation) collection. Explore the template:** Get familiar with the template and get the hang of running end-to-end tests on Postman by going through the documentation provided. <br><br>**Step 2. Build user workflows:** List the main user workflows or scenarios within your application, such as registration, login, data submission, transaction processing, etc. <br><br> **Step 3. Create test scenarios:** Based on the identified user workflows, create test scenarios that cover end-to-end interactions and functionalities. Design tests to simulate real-world user interactions and system behavior. <br><br>**Step 4. Write test scripts:** Update the template or create a new collection and set up requests for your user flows. Develop test scripts for each end-to-end scenario on Postman. Bonus: Use Postbot to generate test scripts instantly. <br><br>**Step 5. Execute end-to-end tests:** Run the end-to-end tests against your application to validate the entire workflow from start to finish. The template demonstrates how to provide a clear overview of test coverage and dependencies. \n\n- **Reduced onboarding time:** The template shows you how to build documentation in a way that helps new team members quickly familiarize themselves with the testing process and application functionalities."},{"key":"2","question":"What are the best practices for end-to-end testing?","answer":"Some best practices for effective end-to-end API testing include: \n- **Prioritizing critical scenarios:** Focus on testing essential API interactions and workflows. \n\n- **Automation:** Use the Postman Collection Runner or other automation tools and frameworks to automate repetitive API test cases. \n\n- **Data management:** Ensure proper setup and management of test data to simulate realistic usage scenarios. \n\n- **Environment consistency:** Maintain consistent testing environments to minimize variability in test results. \n\n- **Collaboration:** Foster collaboration between development and QA teams to align testing efforts with business objectives and requirements."}],"meta":{"faqHeader":"FAQs about the end-to-end testing template"}},"relatedTemplates":["78475d97-9a36-4731-ab24-9adf6a94d0fb","7ab0f80e-a964-46ee-b948-4a4e3a85809c","3302192d-87dd-4612-b381-61894de21203","42247877-8529-429d-acba-4de20c3b5b3b"],"meta":{"pageMeta":{"title":"End-to-end API Testing Template | Postman Templates","description":"Discover how to create and organize end-to-end test cases for your API by using this template.","keywords":"End-to-end testing, end-to-end testing template"},"bannerHeader":"Discover how to create and organize end-to-end tests on Postman"},"transactionId":null,"suggested":true,"recommended":true,"icon":"integration-testing-icon","collectionDescription":"> This collection features end-to-end tests that ensure the Intergalactic Bank API components function in an expected sequence. Check out the [Functional testing collection](https://www.postman.com/templates/f26ad070-d626-4d75-b151-7cbf1a48ed11/Functional-testing) and [Integration testing collection](https://www.postman.com/templates/6f788c17-067a-4074-a528-d07df1df9529/Integration-testing-%23example) for other test cases for this API. \n  \n\n## **🪐 Get started**\n\nThe fictional Intergalactic Bank Services team is responsible for testing the end-to-end workflows in this collection. You can use this collection to validate specific workflows for your team or figure out ways to increase your test coverage and make your applications more resilient.\n\nTo test the Intergalactic Bank API, you can:\n\n1. **Review tests and scripts:** Check out the [tests](https://learning.postman.com/docs/writing-scripts/test-scripts/) in the Scripts tab of a collection, folder, or request. You’ll also find additional steps in the Pre-request Script, such as for passing data between requests or building up POST request payloads.\n    \n2. **Run tests:** To run the collection, select Run collection from the collection menu. If you are interested in testing one of the use cases, select Run folder from the use case folder menu. Keep in mind that many of these tests contain logic that passes information between requests, and they are meant to be run in order from top to bottom. If you send the requests manually or out of order, your results may vary.\n    \n3. **Review test results:** Many of the test cases contain error messages to help debug service errors. If you’re using this collection as a pre-merge check, ensure that all tests are passing before submitting (and no, deleting the failing test cases isn’t an option 😉).\n    \n\nCheck out the additional sections below or select View complete documentation. For context-sensitive help with a folder or request, look for the documentation icon.\n\n## 🧑‍💻How your team can use this collection\n\n- **Add a mock server to speed up development:** Adding functionality to this service? Since this collection has example responses, you can add a mock server that will return the expected results. Start writing tests against the mock, and once your additions are live, you can swap out the URLs and have a live test suite.\n    \n- **Integrate tests with your CI/CD pipeline:** This comprehensive test suite is a great addition to your existing CI/CD pipeline. Generate the Postman CLI command from the Collection Runner and add this step to your existing checks each time you make a commit affecting this service.\n    \n- **Add a monitor:** If your team is contributing to or relying on this service, it’s a good idea to keep tabs on the status. Adding a monitor to this collection can give you confidence that the service is up and running and alert you to any breaking changes that may have occurred.\n    \n\n## 🔍 What we’re testing\n\n- A very common workflow is the transfer of funds between accounts. We have two scenarios: one which creates all resources and successfully transfers funds, and one which tries the transfer with insufficient funds.\n    \n- During these workflows, we are testing for data correctness, data types, and that data is successfully passed through the system during creation and retrieval.\n    \n\n## 🔒A note on authorization\n\nThis API uses an API key-based authorization. In this collection, we set the authorization at the collection level and generate a new API Key for each test run.\n\n## 👀 View and share run results\n\nInterested in seeing previous run results? We’re happy to share, and have a few ways for you to stay in the loop:\n\n- **Runs tab:** View past collection runs in the `Runs` tab of this collection. Here, you can see the results of past runs, including who ran them and whether it was via the Collection Runner or the CLI. You can also share individual run reports from this page.\n    \n- **Monitors:** If you have a monitor set up for this collection, you can see historical run information when you select the Monitors tab in the left sidebar. You can also have the results sent to Slack or other services when you set up a corresponding integration.\n    \n\n### 🤝Increase test coverage\n\nThe Intergalactic Bank Services team wants your team to have everything they need to successfully test our services with their applications. You can use this collection to familiarize yourself with the service and its expected behavior or validate that the changes you make to this service conform to the requirements.\n\nSteps to test the Intergalactic Bank API:\n\n1. **Review tests and scripts:** [Tests](https://learning.postman.com/docs/writing-scripts/test-scripts/) are written under the Scripts tab at the folder and request levels. Different testing requirements are distributed between the folders, so be sure to read the documentation for each folder to understand what is being tested.\n    \n2. **Run tests:** To run the collection, navigate to Run Collection from the collection menu. Note that the Setup folder creates and stores resources that will be tested in the Account Tests folder, so these setup requests should always be a prerequisite.\n    \n3. **Review test results:** We have included error messages for many of the test cases to help debug what may be wrong with the service. If using this collection as a pre-merge check, be sure to have all tests passing before submitting (and no, deleting the failing test cases isn’t an option 😉).\n    \n\nFor more details, check out the additional sections below, and click `View Complete Documentation` for the complete documentation. We test data types and workflows in our other collections.\n    \n- Each of our test requests is named after a specific business rule we are evaluating, and these rules correspond to our stakeholder’s specifications.\n    \n- Our setup and teardown requests are only tested for status code to make sure they run successfully. These endpoints are tested more in depth in our other collections.\n    \n\n## 🧑‍💻How your team can use this collection:\n\n- **Add a mock server to speed up development:** Adding functionality to this service? You can use this as a reference when creating your API prototype.\"","target":["modal"]},{"header":"Recommended for","description":"","list":["Backend Developers","QA Engineers"],"target":["modal"]},{"header":"Contains","description":"","list":["Requests for the soon-to-be-developed Intergalactic Bank API","Comprehensive documentation","A step-by-step guide for creating a mock server on Postman"],"target":["modal"]},{"header":"Overview","description":"\"Prototyping is a crucial step that can help you speed up your API development workflows. <br><br>This template provides a prototype collection for the soon-to-be-developed Intergalactic Bank API and lists the steps for creating a mock server on Postman. You can use this as a reference when creating your API prototype.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What is an API prototype?","description":"\"An API prototype is a preliminary version of an API that simulates its behavior and functionality without full implementation. It allows you to gather early feedback, validate design decisions, and identify potential issues before investing significant resources into development.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What are the benefits of using an API prototype?","description":"\"Using an API prototype offers the following key advantages in the API development process: <br><br>**Early validation:** An API prototype enables you to gather feedback from developers and product managers and address potential issues early on. <br><br>**Alignment with requirements:** By providing a tangible representation of the API's functionality and design, an API prototype facilitates alignment with project requirements. <br><br>**Reduce dependency delays:** API prototypes empower frontend developers to start work without backend dependencies, accelerating overall development timelines.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What does the API prototyping template contain?","description":"\"The API prototyping template provides a prototype collection for the soon-to-be-developed Intergalactic Bank API, which includes comprehensive documentation and a step-by-step guide for mocking an API on Postman.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"How to use our API prototyping template?","description":"\"You can use the template to create your API prototype in four simple steps: <br><br> **Step 1. Create a sample mock server:** Follow the step-by-step guide provided in the documentation to create and test your first API mock server on Postman. <br><br> **Step 3. Implement your mock server:** Add a new collection with requests for your new service. Create examples of responses and use them to build your mock server. You can then apply these techniques to build mock servers for new services you’re building."},{"key":"2","question":"Can I use API prototyping for iterative development processes?","answer":"Absolutely! An API prototype is well-suited for iterative development processes. You can quickly iterate on the API prototype based on feedback and changing requirements and ensure that the final API meets the needs of stakeholders and end-users."}],"meta":{"faqHeader":"FAQs about the prototype template"}},"relatedTemplates":[],"meta":{"pageMeta":{"title":"API Prototyping Template | Postman Templates","description":"Use our API prototyping template to explore how to build a mock server on Postman and accelerate your API development process.","keywords":"API prototyping, API prototype, API mock"},"bannerHeader":"Create your API prototype in a few simple steps"},"transactionId":null,"suggested":true,"recommended":true,"icon":"integration-testing-icon","collectionDescription":"> Prototyping your API in Postman streamlines the development process by enabling you to design and test front- and back-end API-driven functionalities within a shared workspace. \n  \n\n## **🪐 Get started**\n\nThis collection serves as a place for teams from the Intergalactic Bank to collaborate on the design of the soon-to-be-developed Intergalactic Bank API. This prototype collection outlines how the service's requests and responses should function. Stakeholders should provide their thoughts and suggestions before we begin development.\n\n## **🧑‍💻 Setting up a mock server**\n\n<img src=\"https://lh7-us.googleusercontent.com/eNxPYjGNGALmKSzZvdhlMuy_XK3C_iQ3rK7tCDiPvr6nePMyggp9NTIAjcZYs7oIy8PU_NCGFKtcBPRZrfplfPyrKsO5SCMRX6OuBpzsL_HuOHxW2DwA3FH2-o0uFJgAZOr7JaQTiIvkayUSrPdsxQQ\">\n\nThis collection is meant to be used alongside a [<b>Postman Mock Server</b>](https://learning.postman.com/docs/designing-and-developing-your-api/mocking-data/setting-up-mock/)**.** Since we are still in the planning phase of the API, we have included several example responses for each request, laying out how we think each possible response will look. Including these example responses also has the added benefit of powering a mock server. By following the instructions, you can set up your own mock server and simulate the behavior of this API by returning the predefined data.\n\n**To set up a mock server:**\n\n1. Select **Mock collection** from the collection's actions menu.\n2. On the **Create a mock server** page, add a name for your mock server, and select to **Save the mock server URL as a new environment variable.** This will create a new environment with the mock’s URL pre-populated.\n3. Select the **New Environment** from the **Environment** dropdown list.\n4. Complete the process by clicking **Create Mock Server**.\n5. Send the request! You should now see that the `{{url}}` variable is using the mock server you set up previously.\n6. Try editing fields in the mocked responses to see your changes reflected in the mock server.\n    \n\n## **🤔Why include tests?**\n\nEach request in the collection includes tests to check the response structure. These tests check that all of the properties that other systems rely on are present and of the expected data type. Once you have the fully built-out service in place, you can swap the mock server URL for the live URL and test that your implementation follows the same guidelines as your prototype. This gives you confidence that you can start integrating this service into your systems.\n\nIf you are adding a new proposed endpoint for this request, try asking Postbot to generate tests for it.\n\n## **🤝Collaborate with us!**\n\nThe Bank Services team wants your team’s input on our API design. Add an [inline comment](https://learning.postman.com/docs/collaborating-in-postman/working-with-your-team/discussing-your-work/) to this collection with your ideas, questions, and suggestions, or reach out to us on our internal Slack by tagging `@bank-services`.","categories":{"Roles":["Backend Developers","Fullstack Developers","Frontend Developers"],"Use cases":["Prototyping"]}},{"id":"fe506090-ca91-4340-bea9-82d2c3d2bb9a","name":"Integration testing basics","category":"Use cases","illustration":"https://skills-assets.pstmn.io/collection-templates/integration-testing.gif","downloadCount":174484,"iconUrl":"https://skills-assets.pstmn.io/collection-templates/integration-testing-icon.svg","description":"Verify if your APIs work as expected.","summary":[{"header":"Overview","description":"\"As your application evolves, it’s important to verify that different modules work together as expected. With this template, you can test how various modules (route, validation, application, data layer) interact with each other.\"","target":["landing page","modal"]},{"header":"Recommended for","description":"","list":["Quality Engineers","Backend Developers"],"target":["modal"]},{"header":"Contains","description":"\"Requests and test scripts for testing a workflow that includes:\"","list":["Registering and receiving a token","Using the token to retrieve secret data","Unregistering the token and ensuring secret data can’t be retrieved"],"target":["modal"]},{"header":"What is integration testing?","description":"\"Integration testing is the process of testing multiple modules or components of an application together to ensure that they work harmoniously as a unified system. In the context of APIs, integration testing refers to the process of testing how different API endpoints, modules, or services interact with each other.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What does API integration testing involve?","description":"\"API integration testing involves testing the interaction and data exchange between different API endpoints and services. With API integration testing, you can validate that the APIs communicate correctly, produce accurate responses, and handle data flow consistently when integrated with other components of the application.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What does the integration testing template contain?","description":"\"The integration testing template contains a collection of sample requests and reusable test scripts that facilitate testing a workflow involving multiple API interactions. Specifically, the template covers test scenarios related to:\\n\\n - Registering and receiving a token\\n\\n\\n - Using the token to retrieve secret data\\n\\n\\n - Unregistering the token and data protection\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"How to perform API integration testing with the template?","description":"\"By following these steps, you can effectively test API integrations to ensure that various modules or services work together as expected:<br><br>**Step 1. Understand the template:** Familiarize yourself with the contents and purpose of the template. Read the documentation provided to interact with the template and get the hang of performing integration tests on Postman.<br><br>**Step 2. Customize the template:** Tailor the pre-configured tests within the template to suit your API endpoints, data, and specific testing requirements.<br><br>**Step 3. Set up a testing environment (optional):** Create an environment with the necessary configurations, such as authentication details and environment variables.<br><br>**Step 4. Execute the tests:** Run the customized tests to simulate the integration between different API endpoints and validate their interactions.<br><br>**Step 5. Handle test failures:** In case of test failures, promptly investigate and address the root cause of the issues. Update the test cases as needed to reflect API changes or accommodate new requirements.\"","target":["landing page"]}],"faq":{"data":[{"key":"1","question":"What are the benefits of using the template?","answer":"With the integration testing template, you can efficiently test the integration of different API endpoints and verify that your application functions cohesively. Here are three key benefits of using the template:\n\n- **Holistic validation:** Ensure that APIs work harmoniously together by performing a comprehensive assessment of the application's overall functionality.\n\n- **Identifying interaction issues:** Catch potential issues or inconsistencies that arise when different APIs interact and proactively prevent defects in the integrated system.\n\n- **Enhanced software reliability:** You can improve your application's overall reliability and performance by validating the interaction between different APIs."},{"key":"2","question":"API testing vs integration testing: What's the difference?","answer":"While the terms API testing and integration testing might be used interchangeably, these two tests are different.\n\nAPI testing focuses on verifying individual API endpoints' functionality and responses, ensuring each endpoint works as intended in isolation.\n\nOn the other hand, integration testing examines how different APIs interact and cooperate within the application's architecture, validating the integration points and data flow between components."}],"meta":{"faqHeader":"FAQs about the integration testing template"}},"relatedTemplates":[],"meta":{"pageMeta":{"title":"Integration Testing Template | Postman","description":"Learn what integration testing is and get hands-on with testing interactions between APIs using Postman’s integration testing template.","keywords":"API integration testing, Integration testing template"},"bannerHeader":"Reduce the effort needed for robust API integration testing"},"transactionId":null,"suggested":true,"recommended":true,"icon":"integration-testing-icon","collectionDescription":"# ⛓️ Get started here\n\nPostman allows you to test your APIs using simple Javascript code. You can evaluate your response body, headers, cookies, and more using the [ChaiJS BDD](https://www.chaijs.com/api/bdd/) syntax.\n\nThis template guides you through the process of setting up an integration test to ensure that all individual components of an API function together seamlessly.\n\nThe API under test in this collection includes three endpoints for registering and receiving a token, accessing your unique generated name, and unregistering a token:\n\n- POST `/register`\n- POST `/unregister`\n- GET `/my-name`\n    \n\nBy setting up requests in the order of the operation, we can test the flow of data to and from the endpoints and ensure they work together as expected. This example showcases logical workflows for internal consumers using the fictional Intergalactic Bank API. \n  \n\n### **Table of contents:**\n\n> 🚀 Using this workflow collection  \n🔐 Authorization  \n✍️ Example Responses  \n🤔 Need Help? \n  \n\n### 🚀 Using this workflow collection\n\nEach folder in this collection represents a common scenario where the Intergalactic Bank API may be used. In the folder-level documentation, we give an overview of the use case.\n\nAt the request level, we get into even more specifics - check the request's documentation to see notes on how this request is used in the workflow, and check the **Scripts** tabs for scripts to help automate the process.\n\n<img src=\"https://content.pstmn.io/b66e6f9a-78fe-4f43-a841-f536074a701c/UGFyYW1zLmdpZg==\">\n\n## 🔐 Authorization\n\n- The Intergalactic Bank API uses an **API Key** for authorization.\n    \n- You must include an API key in each request to the Postman API with the `x-api-key` request header.\n    \n- A temporary API key has been pre-filled as a [collection variable](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/variables/). The authorization has been set up at the collection level, so all requests in this collection will automatically inherit the needed header.\n    \n\n> ⚠ Don’t leak your secrets! Initial values are saved, and can be shared with others in team workspaces. Current values are local values that are not saved, and won't be persisted in the original shared collection, environment, or globals. [Learn more about variables in Postman](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/variables/#initial-and-current-values) \n  \n<img src=\"https://content.pstmn.io/f4c35120-7080-43b4-8144-483c346498f3/V29ya2Zsb3cgdmFyaWFibGVzLmdpZg==\" alt=\"\" height=\"396\" width=\"513\">\n\n## ✍️ Example Responses\n\nWe have documented many of the possible responses you might encounter using [Examples](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/examples/) under each request.\n\n### 🤔 **Need help?**\n\nThe Bank Services team wants to ensure that your team has everything they need to successfully integrate our services into your applications and services. It helps ensure consistency and completeness in documenting various aspects of the API, such as endpoints, parameters, headers, and responses.<br><br> Postman’s documentation templates allow you to focus on the content and organization of your documentation without starting from scratch. By using the template, you can save time and effort in creating well-structured and informative API documentation.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What does the API documentation template contain?","description":"\"The API documentation template includes a customizable draft and contextual guidelines for the following sections:\\n\\n\\n- Introduction \\n\\n\\n- Authorization details \\n\\n\\n- Folders, requests, parameters, and headers \\n\\n\\n- Examples of various responses\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"How to use the API documentation template?","description":"\"The template serves as a great reference for learning how to structure and format your API documentation effectively and make it easier for developers to understand and consume your API. You can use the template as a starting point for documenting your API or replace the content given in brackets (()) with your API's details to make it your own.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"Best practices for API documentation","description":"\"When it comes to API documentation, following best practices can greatly enhance its usability and effectiveness. Some key best practices include:\\n\\n\\n- **Provide clear and concise explanations:** Ensure your documentation is easy to understand and follow by providing clear explanations for each API endpoint, parameter, and response. Use simple language and avoid technical jargon whenever possible.\\n\\n\\n- **Include code examples:** Help developers understand how to use your API by providing code examples in multiple programming languages. These examples should demonstrate how to make requests, handle responses, and include any necessary headers or parameters.\\n\\n\\n- **Document error handling:** Explain the different types of errors that can occur when using your API and how to handle them. Provide error codes, descriptions, and potential solutions to common errors.\\n\\n\\n- **Include interactive features:** If possible, provide interactive features like an API console or playground that allows developers to make requests and see responses in real-time. This can greatly aid understanding and experimentation.\\n\\n\\n- **Keep documentation up to date:** Regularly review and update your API documentation to ensure it accurately reflects the current state of your API. Document any changes, updates, or deprecations to help developers stay informed.\"","target":["landing page"]}],"faq":{"data":[{"key":"1","question":"What are the benefits of using the API documentation template?","answer":"By using the template, you create documentation that adheres to best practices in a very short span of time. They also offer extensive guides and tutorials to help developers get started quickly.\n\n- **GitHub API:** GitHub's API documentation is known for its clarity and organization. Make sure to cover everything required to reach success with your API as quickly as possible.`\n\nTo start using the ((add APIs here)), you need to -\n\n`The points given below are from The Postman API's documentation. You can reference it to write your own getting started guide.`\n\n- You must use a valid API Key to send requests to the API endpoints. You can get your API key from Postman's [integrations dashboard](https://go.postman.co/settings/me/api-keys).\n- The API has [rate and usage limits](https://learning.postman.com/docs/developer/postman-api/postman-api-rate-limits/).\n- The API only responds to HTTPS-secured communications. Any requests sent via HTTP return an HTTP 301 redirect to the corresponding HTTPS resources.\n- The API returns request responses in JSON format. When an API request returns an error, it is sent in the JSON response as an error key.\n    \n\n## Authentication\n\n`Add details on the authorization keys/tokens required, steps that cover how to get them, and the relevant error codes.`\n\nThe ((product name)) API uses ((add your API's authorization type)) for authentication.\n\n`The details given below are from the Postman API's documentation. You can reference it to write your own authentication section.`\n\nPostman uses API keys for authentication. You can generate a Postman API key in the [API keys](https://postman.postman.co/settings/me/api-keys) section of your Postman account settings.\n\nYou must include an API key in each request to the Postman API with the X-Api-Key request header.\n\n### Authentication error response\n\nIf an API key is missing, malformed, or invalid, you will receive an HTTP 401 Unauthorized response code.\n\n## Rate and usage limits\n\n`Use this section to cover your APIs' terms of use. Include API limits, constraints, and relevant error codes, so consumers understand the permitted API usage and practices.`\n\n`The example given below is from The Postman API's documentation. Use it as a reference to write your APIs' terms of use.`\n\nAPI access rate limits apply at a per-API key basis in unit time. The limit is 300 requests per minute. Also, depending on your plan, you may have usage limits. If you exceed either limit, your request will return an HTTP 429 Too Many Requests status code.\n\nEach API response returns the following set of headers to help you identify your use status:\n\n| Header | Description |\n| --- | --- |\n| `X-RateLimit-Limit` | The maximum number of requests that the consumer is permitted to make per minute. |\n| `X-RateLimit-Remaining` | The number of requests remaining in the current rate limit window. |\n| `X-RateLimit-Reset` | The time at which the current rate limit window resets in UTC epoch seconds. |\n\n### 503 response\n\nAn HTTP `503` response from our servers indicates there is an unexpected spike in API access traffic. The server is usually operational within the next five minutes. If the outage persists or you receive any other form of an HTTP `5XX` error, [contact support](https://support.postman.com/hc/en-us/requests/new/).\n\n### **Need some help?**\n\n`Add links that customers can refer to whenever they need help.`\n\nIn case you have questions, go through our tutorials ((link to your video or help documentation here)). Or visit our FAQ page ((link to the relevant page)).\n\nOr you can check out our community forum, there’s a good chance our community has an answer for you. It involves creating and testing complex conditional workflows, looping through data arrays, chaining requests, and making branching decisions based on API responses. This comprehensive approach allows you to mimic real-world usage scenarios, providing a more accurate assessment of your API's performance.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"Examples of scenario testing","description":"\"\\n- **User registration flow:** Testing the journey from validation and authentication to account creation.\\n\\n\\n- **Role simulation:** Ensuring diverse user roles and permissions to maintain proper access controls.\\n\\n\\n- **Error validation:** Deliberately triggering errors in different API sections to validate error-handling mechanisms.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"Why is API scenario testing important?","description":"\"API scenario testing is essential for uncovering potential issues that might not be apparent during individual endpoint testing. It helps identify how well your API handles complex interactions and dependencies, offering a more realistic evaluation of its reliability and robustness.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What does the API scenario testing template contain?","description":"\"The template serves as a scenario testing playbook and gives you a systematic way to structure and execute tests. Realistic scenarios provide more meaningful insights into how the API performs in a production-like environment.\\n\\n\\n- **Data variation:** Test with a diverse set of input data to account for different use cases. Include data that represents both common and edge cases.\\n\\n\\n- **Error scenarios:**Include scenarios that intentionally induce errors to verify error-handling mechanisms. This template demonstrates how to set up tests to spot deviations from the contract’s specifications for endpoints, parameters, and request/response schemas.\""},{"header":"Recommended for","description":"","list":["Quality Engineers","Backend Developers","Fullstack Developers","Frontend Developers","Technical Architect","DevOps Engineers"],"target":["modal"]},{"header":"Contains","description":"\"Sample requests with test scripts for validating that:\"","list":["The response code is 200, and the response is a JSON object","The response contains an ’arg’ object, a ’headers’ object, and a ’URL’ property","The response code and the data returned in the response is the same as the one being sent","The request body sent as form-data is valid"],"target":["modal"]},{"header":"What is contract testing?","description":"\"Contract testing is a testing approach in API development that verifies the compatibility between the producer (the service owner) and consumer (entities that consume the service) of an API. It ensures that the API's implementation adheres to the predefined contract or specifications agreed upon by both parties. Contract testing ensures the consumer and producer can interact seamlessly without deviations from the established contract.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What are the benefits of API contract testing?","description":"\"Here are some advantages of contract testing:\\n\\n- **Improved collaboration:** Contract testing facilitates better communication and cooperation between API consumers and producers, as they agree on the contract's specifications beforehand.\\n\\n\\n- **Early detection of incompatibilities:** By validating the adherence to the contract, contract testing helps identify any incompatibilities or deviations early in the development process, reducing integration issues later on.\\n\\n\\n- **Increased reliability:** Contract testing enhances the reliability of the API, as it ensures that both parties understand and comply with the contract's terms, leading to a more stable and predictable API behavior.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What is the contract testing template?","description":"\"The contract testing template is a pre-configured collection of requests and reusable test scripts that demonstrates how to conduct contract testing. It includes test scenarios that validate if the API implementation aligns with the agreed-upon contract specifications, ensuring a seamless interaction between the consumer and producer of the API.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What does the contract testing template contain?","description":"\"The contract testing template contains sample requests along with test scripts to perform various contract tests, including:\\n\\n- **Response code and JSON validation:** Verifying that the API responds with a 200 status code and returns a valid JSON object in the response.\\n\\n\\n- **Response structure verification:** Validating that the response contains specific objects, headers, and URL properties as the contract requires.\\n\\n\\n- **Response data consistency:** Ensuring that the response data matches the data sent in the request, verifying that the API handles data consistency correctly.\\n\\n\\n- **Form-data validation:** Checking the validity of the form-data sent in the request body.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"How to use the template to perform contract testing?","description":"\"By following the steps listed below, you can effectively perform contract testing on Postman -<br><br>**Step 1. Execute the tests:** Run the customized tests to validate that the API implementation meets the contract's specifications.\"","target":["landing page"]}],"faq":{"data":[{"key":"1","question":"What types of contract testing can you perform with the template?","answer":"The template equips you to engage in two primary forms of contract testing:\n\n**Consumer-driven contract testing**\n\n This approach places API consumers in the driver's seat as they define the contract based on their unique requirements and expectations. Subsequently, API producers construct the API to align with these contract specifications. This method empowers consumers to shape the contract, ensuring precise alignment with their API utilization needs.\n\n**Provider-driven contract testing**\n\n Here, API producers take charge by defining the contract based on their API's capabilities and functions. Consumers then design their applications to adhere to this established contract. This mode enables producers to establish contract expectations and API capabilities, offering guidance to consumers on effective interaction patterns."},{"key":"2","question":"Contract testing vs integration testing: What’s the difference?","answer":"Contract testing and integration testing are two distinct types of testing used in software development, each serving different purposes. Let's explore the differences between the two:\n\n**Integration testing**\n\nIntegration testing is a type of testing that focuses on verifying the interactions between different components or modules of a system. Integration testing aims to ensure that individual components, when combined, work as expected and produce the desired outcomes. The components can include software modules, services, APIs, databases, and external systems.\n\nIn integration testing, the goal is to detect issues related to data flow, communication, and the overall integration of different parts of the system. It aims to catch bugs that may arise due to miscommunication or incompatible interfaces between components. Integration testing can be performed in various ways, such as top-down, bottom-up, or a combination of both.\n\n**Contract testing**\n\nOn the other hand, contract testing is a testing approach that focuses on verifying the compatibility and adherence to the agreed-upon interfaces (contracts) between different services or microservices within a distributed system. These contracts define each service's expected inputs, outputs, and behavior.\n\nIn a microservices architecture, where services are developed independently and communicate with each other via APIs, contract testing helps ensure that the integration between services remains intact. This type of testing is essential to prevent any breaking changes to the APIs of one service from causing failures in other services that rely on those APIs.\n\nContract testing verifies that the contracts between services are not violated during updates, deployments, or changes to the services. It ensures that each service produces and consumes data in a manner that complies with the specified contracts.\n\nIn summary, the main differences between contract testing and integration testing are:\n\n* Integration testing focuses on testing interactions between different components of a system, while contract testing specifically targets the interfaces (contracts) between services or microservices.\n* Integration testing aims to detect issues related to data flow and communication between components, whereas contract testing aims to ensure that services adhere to their agreed-upon contracts.\n* Integration testing is typically performed within the context of a single application or system, while contract testing is commonly applied in a distributed microservices architecture to validate communication between services."}],"meta":{"faqHeader":"FAQs about the contract testing template"}},"relatedTemplates":[],"meta":{"pageMeta":{"title":"Contract Testing | Postman","description":"Learn what contract testing is and how to conduct it. Bonus: Get hands-on with testing API contracts using Postman’s free template.","keywords":"Contract testing, API contract testing, Postman contract testing"},"bannerHeader":"Speed up the process of testing API contracts"},"transactionId":null,"suggested":false,"recommended":false,"icon":"integration-testing-icon","collectionDescription":"# 🤝 Get started here\n\nThis template demonstrates how to set up contract tests to ensure that two separate systems are compatible and can communicate with one another.\n\nIt contains requests and test scripts for validating the data returned by an API, including the different aspects of a response, query parameters, and form data.\n\n## 🔖 **How to use this collection**\n\n**Step 1:** Send the sample requests and view the response and test results.\n\n**Step 2:** Replace the sample request URLs with your desired API endpoints.\n\n**Step 3:** Customize the tests in the \"Scripts\" tab if needed. Don't forget to save your changes.\n\n### ℹ️ Resources\n\n[Scripting in Postman](https://learning.postman.com/docs/writing-scripts/intro-to-scripts/)\n\n[Test script examples](https://learning.postman.com/docs/writing-scripts/script-references/test-examples/)\n\n[Using the Collection Runner](https://learning.postman.com/docs/collections/running-collections/intro-to-collection-runs/)\n\n[](https://postman.postman.co/documentation/24552533-5bead607-0197-4e1d-87d4-3160bc7631c1?entity=&branch=&version=)","categories":{"Use cases":["Testing"],"Roles":["Backend Developers"]}},{"id":"31a9a6ed-4cdf-4ced-984c-d12c9aec1c27","name":"Authorization methods","category":"Use cases","illustration":"https://skills-assets.pstmn.io/collection-templates/auth-method.gif","downloadCount":99115,"iconUrl":"https://skills-assets.pstmn.io/collection-templates/auth-method-icon.svg","description":"Learn more about different authorization types and quickly set up auth helpers for your API in Postman.","summary":[{"header":"Overview","description":"\"Use the customizable examples in this template to understand how to set up auth helpers for Basic Auth, OAuth 2.0/1.0, Token auth, and other types of authorization in Postman and get started quickly.\""},{"header":"Recommended for","description":"","list":["Backend Developers","Fullstack Developers","Frontend Developers"],"target":["modal"]},{"header":"Contains","description":"\"Examples and step-by-step guides for:\"","list":["Basic Auth","OAuth 1.0","OAuth 2.0","Bearer Token","Generating signed JWTs","API Key","Hawk Auth","Digest Auth"],"target":["modal"]},{"header":"What are authorization methods?","description":"\"Authorization methods are mechanisms used to authenticate and grant access to protected resources within an API or web application. These methods may include Basic Auth, OAuth 1.0, OAuth 2.0, Bearer Token, generating signed JWTs, API Key, Hawk Auth, and Digest Auth. Each method has its own requirements, workflow, and security considerations.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What does the authorization methods template contain?","description":"\"It contains examples and step-by-step guidelines for working with:\\n\\n\\n- Basic Auth \\n\\n\\n- OAuth 1.0 \\n\\n\\n- OAuth 2.0 \\n\\n\\n- Bearer Token \\n\\n\\n- Generating signed JWTs \\n\\n\\n- API Key \\n\\n\\n- Hawk Auth \\n\\n\\n- Digest Auth\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"How to use the authorization methods template?","description":"\"The template includes definitions, interactive examples, and guides for various authorization methods available on Postman. By following the in-built documentation, you can quickly set up auth helpers in Postman and gain a solid understanding of how to implement different authorization methods in your API testing and development workflows.\"","target":["landing page"]}],"faq":{"data":[{"key":"1","question":"What types of authorization are used in web applications?","answer":"There are various types of authorization commonly used in web applications and APIs. Some of the common types covered in the authorization methods template include:\n\n- **Role-based Authorization:** This type of authorization grants access based on the user's assigned role or permissions within the system.\n\n- **Token-based Authorization:** Token-based authorization involves the use of tokens, such as JWTs (JSON Web Tokens) or bearer tokens, to authenticate and authorize access to resources.\n\n- **OAuth Authorization:** OAuth is an open standard authorization protocol used for delegated access, allowing third-party applications to access resources on behalf of the user.\n\n- **API Key Authorization:** API Key authorization involves the use of an API key, a unique identifier, to authenticate and authorize access to APIs.\n\n- **Digest Authentication:** Digest authentication is a challenge-response-based authentication mechanism that uses hashing to protect credentials during the authentication process.\n\nThese are just a few examples of the different types of authorization. The authorization method template provides examples and guides for various types, helping you understand their implementation and usage."},{"key":"2","question":"Authorization vs authentication: what's the difference?","answer":"Authorization and authentication are related but distinct concepts. Authentication is the process of verifying the identity of a user or entity, ensuring they are who they claim to be. It typically involves presenting credentials, such as a username and password, to gain access to a system or resource.\n\nOn the other hand, authorization is the process of granting or denying access to specific resources or functionalities based on the authenticated user's permissions or roles. Once a user is authenticated, authorization determines what actions or data they are allowed to access within the system.<br><br>In summary, authentication verifies the user's identity, while authorization controls the user's access to resources or actions within a system."}]},"relatedTemplates":[],"meta":{"pageMeta":{"title":"Authorization Types and Methods | Postman","description":"Use the definitions and examples in this resource to learn about popular authorization types available on Postman and how you can use them for API testing.","keywords":"types of authorization, authorization types"},"bannerHeader":"Learn more about different authorization methods on Postman"},"transactionId":null,"suggested":false,"recommended":false,"icon":"integration-testing-icon","collectionDescription":"# 🔐 Get started here\n\nPostman supports a range of [authorization](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/authorization/) mechanisms to enable you to communicate securely with APIs.\n\nThis template contains examples of different types of authorization that are ready to be modified to fit your use case.\n\n- **Basic Auth:** This simple authorization method uses a username and password combination to grant access to API resources. Postman offers a built-in Basic Auth helper that makes it easy to include the required credentials in your API requests.\n    \n\n- **OAuth 1.0 & OAuth 2.0:** Postman supports both versions of the OAuth protocol, which involve complex flows including obtaining request tokens, user authorization, and exchanging tokens for access tokens. Postman streamlines this process by handling server-side interactions, managing tokens, and offering pre-built authorization helpers.\n    \n\n- **Bearer Token:** Commonly used with OAuth 2.0, this method involves sending a token in the request header to authenticate with the API.\n    \n\n- **API Key:** Postman supports API Key authorization, which requires including a unique key in the request headers or as a query parameter.\n    \n\n- **Digest Auth:** This method employs a challenge-response mechanism to ensure secure communication with APIs.\n    \n\n- **Hawk Authentication:** Postman supports the Hawk authorization method, which utilizes time-based, one-time-use tokens for secure API access.\n    \n\n## 🔖 **How to use this template**\n\n**Step 1:** Select the request for your relevant authorization type.\n\n**Step 2:** Check out the documentation for the selected request to learn more about the type of authorization and how to use it.\n\n**Step 3:** Complete the relevant details for your selected authorization type.\n\n(Note: The correct data values will be determined by your API on the server side. If you're using a third-party API, refer to the provider's documentation for more details about the required authorization type.)\n\n## 💡Related templates\n\n[API testing It provides a practical guide for writing tests and covers important concepts of API testing. By using the API testing basics template, you can gain hands-on experience in writing effective API tests that ensure the quality and reliability of your APIs.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What are the different types of API tests?","description":"\" - **Unit testing:** Tests individual functions or methods within the API to ensure they work correctly and produce the expected outputs.\\n\\n\\n- **Functional testing:** Validates the functional requirements of the API, covering scenarios and verifying that the API performs as intended.\\n\\n\\n- **Integration testing:** Verifies the interaction between multiple components or systems, ensuring seamless communication and data exchange.\\n\\n\\n- **Performance testing:** Evaluates the performance and scalability of the API under various load conditions, measuring response times, throughput, and resource utilization.\\n\\n\\n- **Security testing:** Focuses on identifying vulnerabilities and weaknesses in the API's security measures, ensuring the protection of sensitive data and preventing unauthorized access.\\n\\n\\n- **Load testing:** Assesses the API's behavior and performance under expected and peak loads, ensuring it can handle the anticipated user traffic without degradation.\\n\\n\\n- **Stress testing:** Pushes the API beyond its capacity limits to identify how it handles extreme loads and measure its resilience under stress conditions.\\n\\n\\n- **Usability testing:** Tests the API's ease of use, including its clarity, user-friendliness, and intuitiveness.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What types of bugs does API testing help detect?","description":"\"API testing helps uncover various types of bugs. Here are the most common ones: \\n\\n\\n- **Functional bugs:** Issues related to incorrect implementation of functionality, such as incorrect responses, missing data, or unexpected behavior.\\n\\n\\n- **Integration bugs:** Problems in integrating different components or systems that affect communication and data flow between them.\\n\\n\\n- **Performance bugs:** Performance-related issues, such as slow response times, high resource consumption, or scalability limitations.\\n\\n\\n- **Security bugs:** Security vulnerabilities, such as authentication and authorization flaws, input validation issues, or exposure of sensitive data.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What are the basic steps involved in API testing?","description":"\"Here are the basic steps involved in API testing: <br><br>**Step 1. Test planning:** Define the scope, objectives, and requirements of API testing. Identify the endpoints to be tested and the expected behaviors. <br><br>**Step 2. Test environment setup:** Prepare the necessary test environment, including setting up test data, configuring test tools, and ensuring the availability of required dependencies. <br><br>**Step 3. Test case design:** Create test cases that cover different scenarios, including positive and negative test cases. Consider functional and non-functional aspects, such as input validation, error handling, and performance. <br><br>**Step 4. Test execution:** Execute the test cases, making API calls and verifying the responses against expected results. Capture relevant test data and log any issues encountered. <br><br>**Step 5. Test reporting:** Document the test results, including any defects or anomalies discovered during testing. Provide clear and detailed reports for easier analysis and issue resolution. <br><br>**Step 6. Test maintenance:** Regularly review and update test cases as the API evolves or changes. Maintain test data and keep the test environment up to date. <br><br>These steps provide a general framework for API testing and can be customized based on the specific requirements of your project.\"","target":["landing page"]}],"faq":{"data":[{"key":"1","question":"Who can use this template?","answer":"The API testing basics template is designed for individuals who want to learn the fundamentals of API testing and improve their skills in sending requests and writing tests on Postman. Here's a brief difference between the two: <br><br>**APIs (Application Programming Interfaces):** APIs allow systems or applications to interact with each other by providing a set of rules and protocols. They enable controlled access to functionality and data by exposing specific endpoints. Developers use APIs to make requests and retrieve or manipulate data. <br><br>**Webhooks:** Webhooks are a way for systems to send real-time notifications or events to other systems. Unlike APIs where the client makes requests to retrieve data, with webhooks, the server sends data to a predefined URL when a specific event or trigger occurs. Webhooks enable asynchronous communication, allowing systems to react to events or update data in real-time. <br><br>In summary, APIs are used for making requests to retrieve or manipulate data, while webhooks are used for pushing notifications or events from a server to another system.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What does the webhooks API template contain?","description":"\"The webhooks API template contains a blueprint that demonstrates how to structure endpoints for setting up, managing, and verifying webhook events. You can choose an authentication method to apply to the whole collection by selecting the collection and navigating to the Authorization tab.\n\n## 🔖 How to use this collection?\n\nThe collection is designed to be flexible and can be customized to meet the specific requirements of your own webhooks API implementation.\n\n#### Step 1: Update the base URL variable\n\nAdd your API's base URL in the `baseUrl` collection variable, replacing the existing dummy endpoint (`https://api.example.com`).\n\n#### Step 2: Create a webhook\n\nStart with `Create Webhook` endpoint to create a webhook and enter the following required information:\n\n- `webhook_url`: the name of the webhook that you're creating\n- `events`: (optional) Events that you want to trigger this webhook with. should be triggered on all events if none was provided.\n    \n\n#### **Step 3: Call the webhook**\n\nProceed to the `Trigger specific webhook` request. So WebSocket APIs enable a seamless bidirectional data flow between a client and a server. Unlike traditional HTTP, WebSockets enable real-time communication, making them ideal for applications requiring instant updates.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"When and why should you use WebSocket APIs?","description":"\"Here are the top benefits of using WebSocket APIs: \\n\\n\\n- **Bidirectional communication:** WebSocket APIs enable both clients and servers to send messages at any time and are a great fit for applications and interactive websites with real-time communication. \\n\\n\\n- **Low latency and efficiency:** Live sports scores, stock trading platforms, and real-time streaming applications leverage WebSockets to reduce overhead and use resources efficiently. \\n\\n\\n- **Push notifications:** Messaging apps, news apps, or any platform where users need to receive instant notifications benefit from WebSocket's ability to push updates without the need for constant polling.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What does the WebSocket basics template contain?","description":"\"The WebSocket basics template contains customizable sample requests demonstrating how to send plain text, JSON, and XML data over a WebSocket.
