You can opt for GraphQL when you want to: \\n\\n\\n- **Manage complex data requirements:** GraphQL allows clients to request only the specific data they need, making it a good fit for applications that have complex data requirements. \\n\\n\\n- **Handle multiple data sources:** When integrating multiple data sources, GraphQL provides a unified endpoint for fetching data, reducing the need for multiple API calls. \\n\\n\\n- **Improve frontend efficiency:** For frontend development, GraphQL helps minimize over-fetching or under-fetching of data, optimizing performance and reducing bandwidth usage. \\n\\n\\n- **Work with real-time updates:** GraphQL subscriptions enable efficient bidirectional communication between clients and servers, which is key for applications requiring real-time updates.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"How to test GraphQL APIs?","description":"\"Testing GraphQL APIs involves a combination of unit testing, integration testing, and end-to-end testing. Learn GraphQL basics and get hands-on experience testing GraphQL APIs on Postman.","keywords":"GraphQL testing, GraphQL Postman"},"bannerHeader":"Test a GraphQL API on Postman in three simple steps","isExtensibleCollection":true},"transactionId":null,"suggested":false,"recommended":false,"icon":"integration-testing-icon","collectionDescription":"# 🚀 Get started here\n\nThis template guides you through principles of GraphQL requests.\n\nGraphQL is designed to make APIs fast, flexible, and developer-friendly. As an alternative to REST, GraphQL enables developers to request specific data from a server by defining a query structure that matches the desired data shape.\n\n## 🔖 **How to use this template**\n\n> Note: To use GraphQL requests in Postman you must be using the [desktop app](https://www.postman.com/downloads/), or the web app with the [Desktop Agent](https://www.postman.com/downloads/postman-agent/) installed. \n  \n\n#### **Step 1: Send requests**\n\nWe recommend you run the requests in this order to explore the collection and understand the different endpoints without running into any hiccups:\n\n1. `Introspection` : This will return the schema for the API. Using this, you can retrieve information about the available types, fields, directives, and more.\n    \n2. `Query` : This request is used to fetch data from a GraphQL API. It allows you to specify the fields and nested relationships you want to retrieve.\n    \n3. `Mutation` : This is used to modify or create data on the server. It is similar to a query but represents an operation that changes the state of the system.\n    \n4. `Subscriptions` : This request enables real-time updates by establishing a persistent connection between the client and the server.\n    \n\n#### **Step 2: View responses**\n\nIn this template, we are using Postman's Echo GraphQL service to mock the responses for the requests. You can view the response in the response panel and verify that the response matches the structure of the query.\n\n#### **Step 3: Customize the requests**\n\nUpdate the different requests to suit your use case, including the query, authorization and documentation. You can add variables to the query to pass dynamic values to a query or mutation. You can reuse the same query structure with different inputs.\n\n#### **Step 4: Try another GraphQL API**\n\nVariables enable you to store and reuse values in Postman. We have created a variable called `base_url` and given it the value of Postman's Echo GraphQL service, `https://graphql.postman-echo.com`. ","summary":[{"header":"Overview","description":"\"This template gives you an overview of the concepts, components, and features of gRPC, including the different types of Remote Procedure Call (RCP) and Protocol Buffers. Use it to understand gRPC fundamentals and get hands-on with sending RCP calls.\""},{"header":"Recommended for","description":"","list":["Backend Developers","Fullstack Developers","Frontend Developers"],"target":["modal"]},{"header":"Contains","description":"Customizable sample requests for the four types of Remote Procedure Call supported by gRPC:","list":["Unary request","Server streaming","Client streaming","Bidirectional streaming"],"target":["modal"]},{"header":"What is gRPC?","description":"\"gRPC, or Remote Procedure Call, is a high-performance open-source RPC framework developed by Google. It uses Protocol Buffers as the interface definition language, allowing efficient communication between distributed systems. gRPC supports various types of RPC calls, making it suitable for building scalable and efficient microservices.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"When and why should you use gRPC APIs?","description":"\"You can consider gRPC when aiming to build modern applications that require efficient communication and cross-language support. Here’s a breakdown of the benefits: \\n\\n\\n- **Swift data transfer:** gRPC's use of Protocol Buffers ensures nimble binary serialization, crucial for bandwidth-sensitive applications. \\n\\n\\n- **Multilingual compatibility:** With gRPC supporting various programming languages, it seamlessly connects services written in different languages. \\n\\n\\n- **Dynamic streaming:** For real-time updates or applications demanding bidirectional streaming, gRPC's streaming methods are a valuable asset. \\n\\n\\n- **Microservices integration:** In microservices setups, gRPC simplifies communication, offering a robust, strongly-typed interface through Protocol Buffers.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What does the gRPC basics template contain?","description":"\"The gRPC basics template is designed to help you understand the fundamental concepts of gRPC and guide you through testing gRPC calls. It includes customizable sample requests that demonstrate the four types of Remote Procedure Calls supported by gRPC: unary, server streaming, client streaming, and bidirectional streaming.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"How to use the template to test gRPC APIs?","description":"\"Once you’ve added the template to your Postman workspace, you can follow the steps below to test gRPC APIs:<br><br> **Step 1: Explore the template:** Get familiar with the template's structure, which includes requests for each type of gRPC call.<br><br>**Step 2. Execute unary request:** Begin by executing unary requests to understand the basic one-to-one communication between the client and the server.<br><br>**Step 3: Explore streaming requests:** Move on to the server streaming, client streaming, and bidirectional streaming requests to explore the different streaming capabilities offered by gRPC.<br><br>**Step 4. Customize sample requests:** Modify the sample requests and the Protocol Buffers to suit your gRPC service specifications.\"","target":["landing page"]}],"faq":{"data":[{"key":"1","question":"Can I extend the template for more complex gRPC scenarios?","answer":"Yes, you can extend the template by incorporating additional gRPC scenarios specific to your use case. The template has been designed to make it easy to customize the foundation provided for more comprehensive testing."},{"key":"2","question":"How does the gRPC basics template help you?","answer":"Our gRPC basics template is your friendly guide to mastering gRPC fundamentals, testing gRPC APIs, and confidently navigating various Remote Procedure Call scenarios. Let’s explore the benefits in detail:\n\n- **Structured learning:** Use the gRPC basics template for a step-by-step exploration of essential concepts, components, and features of gRPC APIs. \n\n- **Hands-on exploration:** Send the sample requests that cover various Remote Procedure Calls to get hands-on experience with testing gRPC APIs. \n\n- **Efficient testing foundation:** The template covers diverse scenarios, letting you adapt it to your unique use cases effortlessly."},{"key":"3","question":"REST vs gRPC: What's the difference?","answer":"REST (Representational State Transfer) and gRPC (gRPC Remote Procedure Calls) are both technologies used for communication between different services in a distributed system, but they have several key differences: \n\n- **Communication protocol:** REST typically relies on HTTP/HTTPS for communication, while gRPC uses HTTP/2 as the default protocol, offering features like multiplexing and bidirectional streaming. \n\n- **Payload format:** In REST, data interchange commonly employs JSON or XML, whereas gRPC utilizes Protocol Buffers (Protobuf) by default, providing a binary serialization format that is more compact and efficient. \n\n- **Message structure:** REST organizes operations (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE) around resources, while gRPC defines service methods and exchanges data using messages and procedures, allowing for more flexibility in complex operations. \n\n- **Flexibility:** REST provides flexibility with a stateless communication model, known for its simplicity and widespread adoption. In contrast, gRPC offers a structured and strongly-typed contract with Protocol Buffers, requiring more upfront definition but potentially leading to more maintainable APIs. \n\n- **IDL (Interface Definition Language):** REST typically lacks a formal IDL, relying on documentation for understanding. Conversely, gRPC requires a formal IDL, using Protocol Buffers to provide clear and enforceable contract definitions. \n\n- **Error handling:** REST uses standard HTTP status codes for error handling, whereas gRPC has its own set of status codes, offering more detailed information about the nature of errors."}],"meta":{"faqHeader":"FAQs about the gRPC basics template"}},"relatedTemplates":["e9a37a28-055b-49cd-8c7e-97494a21eb54","e9c28f47-1253-44af-a2f3-20dce4da1f18","31a9a6ed-4cdf-4ced-984c-d12c9aec1c27","88a124f3-20d3-412a-a6a2-3b58307a7b16"],"meta":{"isExtensibleCollection":true},"transactionId":null,"suggested":false,"recommended":false,"icon":"integration-testing-icon","collectionDescription":"# 🚀 Get started here\n\nThis template guides you through some principles of gRPC requests.\n\n[gRPC](https://grpc.io/docs/what-is-grpc/introduction/) is a Remote Procedure Call framework developed by Google to enable high-performance, cross-platform remote procedure calls. A service's available methods, message, and response interfaces are defined with [Protocol Buffers](https://protobuf.dev/), which are consumed to generate bindings making it easy to call the remote procedures 'directly' from many languages. [HTTP/2](https://web.dev/performance-http2/) is used for transport.\n\nThere are four types of Remote Procedure Call supported by gRPC:\n\n- **Unary RPC**: One request is sent, one response is returned.\n- **Server streaming RPC**: One request is sent, multiple responses are returned. The call is complete when the server indicates when it has finished sending responses.\n- **Client streaming RPC**: Multiple requests are sent, one response is returned (typically after the client has finished sending requests).\n- **Bidirectional streaming RPC**: Requests and responses can be sent freely at any time. The usage is application-specific; the server could collect batches of requests and respond occasionally, it could never respond, or it could respond to every request immediately.\n    \n\nThis collection shows an example of each, using the Postman Echo gRPC service.\n\n## 🔖 **How to use this template**\n\n> Note: To use gRPC requests in Postman you must be using the [desktop app](https://www.postman.com/downloads/), or the web app with the [Desktop Agent](https://www.postman.com/downloads/postman-agent/) installed. \n  \n\n#### **Step 1: Set your name**\n\nIn this collection's 'Variables' tab, set the value of `yourName`. This variable will be used in requests.\n\n#### **Step 2: Send gRPC calls**\n\nEach request shows a different one of the four gRPC call types explained above.\n\nThe Response pane for gRPC is different from the Response pane for HTTP requests, as multiple messages can be sent back and forth in a single gRPC call. While connected, the Response pane is a live view of all incoming _and_ outgoing messages.\n\n#### **Step 3: Send new data**\n\nExperiment with some of the requests by changing message content and sending multiple messages. Note that gRPC uses method definitions, so messages can only include defined parameters.\n\n#### **Step 4: Try another gRPC API**\n\nVariables enable you to store and reuse values in Postman. We have created a variable called `baseUrl` and given it the value of Postman's gRPC Echo service, `grpc.postman-echo.com`. You can change the value in the Variables tab above to point to your own gRPC endpoint or a third party and try sending new messages.\n\n## ℹ️ Resources\n\n[Using gRPC requests](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/grpc/grpc-request-interface/)  \n[Using variables](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/variables/)","categories":{"Postman essentials":["API protocol 101"]}},{"id":"7ab0f80e-a964-46ee-b948-4a4e3a85809c","name":"Regression testing","category":"Use cases","illustration":"https://skills-assets.pstmn.io/collection-templates/regression-testing.gif","downloadCount":9545,"iconUrl":"https://skills-assets.pstmn.io/collection-templates/regression-testing-icon.svg","description":"Check if your API continues to work as expected after introducing changes or updates.","summary":[{"header":"Overview","description":"\"Regression testing is essential to maintaining your API’s overall quality and performance. Use this template to run a series of tests that validate different aspects of your API and ensure everything is still intact post changes or updates.\"","target":["landing page","modal"]},{"header":"Recommended for","description":"","list":["Quality Engineers","Backend Developers"],"target":["modal"]},{"header":"Contains","description":"\"Sample test cases for:\"","list":["Status code verification","JSON schema response validation","Custom response validation","Response time verification","Header verification"],"target":["modal"]},{"header":"What is regression testing?","description":"\"Regression testing is a critical software testing technique used to validate that recent changes, updates, or enhancements to an application or API do not negatively impact existing functionalities. It involves re-running a series of test cases to ensure that the modified code works correctly alongside the other parts of the application and does not introduce new bugs or defects.<br><br> In the context of API testing, regression testing refers to the process of verifying that changes or updates made to an API or its environment do not affect its existing functionality. These changes include fixing a bug, adding a new feature, or improving the API's performance.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What is the regression testing template?","description":"\"The regression testing template is a pre-configured blueprint designed to help quality engineers and backend or fullstack developers perform API regression testing with ease. Understand the template:** Familiarize yourself with the contents and purpose of the template. Read the documentation and guidelines provided.<br><br>**Step 2. Set up a testing environment (optional):** Create an environment with the necessary configurations, such as API endpoints, authentication details, and environment variables. <br><br>**Step 3. Customize the template:** Tailor the pre-configured test cases within the template to suit your API endpoints, data, and specific testing requirements.<br><br>**Step 4. Add data-driven tests:** To enhance the test coverage, consider adding data-driven tests by adding datasets that represent different scenarios, edge cases, or expected outcomes to validate the API's behavior under various conditions.<br><br>**Step 5. Execute the tests:** Run the customized test cases to verify that the API functions correctly after any changes or updates.<br><br>**Step 6. It contains sample requests and [scripts](https://learning.postman.com/docs/writing-scripts/intro-to-scripts/) for a series of tests that validate different aspects of an API, including:\n\n1. **Status code verification:** We'll check if the API returns the expected status codes for various requests, ensuring reliability and proper error handling.\n    \n2. **JSON schema verification:** We'll make sure the JSON response conforms to a specified JSON Schema, ensuring API contracts are honored.\n    \n3. **Response time verification:** We'll verify that the API's response time is within the acceptable range, providing a smooth user experience and optimizing performance.\n    \n4. **Response body verification:** We'll validate the structure and content of the response body for accuracy, ensuring the integrity of the data and preventing potential issues downstream.\n    \n5. **Header verification:** We'll confirm the presence and correct values of specific headers in the response, enabling secure and well-structured communication between your app and its users.\n    \n\n## 🔖 **How to use this template**\n\n**Step 1:** Send the sample requests and view the response and test results.\n\n**Step 2:** Replace the sample request URLs with your desired API endpoints.\n\n**Step 3:** Customize the tests in the \"Scripts\" tab if needed. Don't forget to save your changes.\n\n**Step 4:** [Run the collection](https://learning.postman.com/docs/collections/running-collections/intro-to-collection-runs/) by selecting \"Run\".\n\n<img src=\"https://content.pstmn.io/666cfa65-6e00-4308-871b-f831128bc0ac/Y29sbGVjdGlvbi1ydW5uZXItYnV0dG9uLmpwZWc=\" width=\"246\" height=\"102\">\n\n## 💡Related templates\n\n[Integration testing](https://go.postman.co/redirect/workspace?type=personal&collectionTemplateId=fe506090-ca91-4340-bea9-82d2c3d2bb9a&sourceTemplateId=7ab0f80e-a964-46ee-b948-4a4e3a85809c)  \n[Performance testing](https://go.postman.co/redirect/workspace?type=personal&collectionTemplateId=3302192d-87dd-4612-b381-61894de21203&sourceTemplateId=7ab0f80e-a964-46ee-b948-4a4e3a85809c)  \n[Mock data generation](https://go.postman.co/redirect/workspace?type=personal&collectionTemplateId=da8ceebc-d4da-478c-ab8a-37634faefc74&sourceTemplateId=7ab0f80e-a964-46ee-b948-4a4e3a85809c)  \n[Common API vulnerabilities check](https://go.postman.co/redirect/workspace?type=personal&collectionTemplateId=e1edbae8-6429-453d-890e-00385eea1811&sourceTemplateId=7ab0f80e-a964-46ee-b948-4a4e3a85809c)","categories":{"Use cases":["Testing"],"Roles":["Quality Engineers"]}},{"id":"da8172d0-679b-4173-9104-0ecef2c32cd3","name":"Search API prototype","category":"Industry","illustration":"https://skills-assets.pstmn.io/collection-templates/search-API.png","downloadCount":8277,"iconUrl":"https://skills-assets.pstmn.io/collection-templates/search-API-icon.svg","description":"Access pre-defined endpoints for managing search, autocomplete, popular, and related queries.","summary":[{"header":"Overview","description":"\"This template offers a prototype for a search API. It aims to identify potential performance bottlenecks and assess how well the API performs when subjected to a high number of concurrent users or large amounts of data.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What are the benefits of API performance testing?","description":"\"Here’s a deep dive into the benefits of API performance testing :\\n\\n\\n- **Identifying performance bottlenecks:** Performance testing helps identify areas of the API that may cause slowdowns under heavy usage, allowing for targeted optimizations.\\n\\n\\n- **Ensuring scalability:** By testing performance under different load levels, API performance testing ensures that the API can handle increased traffic and users without performance degradation.\\n\\n\\n- **Enhancing user experience:** A well-performing API leads to a positive user experience, reducing response times and improving overall satisfaction.\\n\\n\\n- **Proactive issue detection:** By conducting performance tests, you can proactively address potential performance issues before they impact users or the application.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What does Postman's performance testing template contain?","description":"\"Postman's performance testing template includes sample API requests and test scripts to evaluate the performance of your API under specific load conditions. It also supports selecting a data file to let you use sets of values in a collection run.\n\nFor each row of data in the input file, Postman will:\n\n- Populate variables for each piece of data.\n- Execute the requests in the collection with access to those variables.\n    \n\nThis powerful feature enables you to perform batch operations with dynamic data.\n\n## 🔖 How to use this template\n\n#### Step 1: Prepare the data file\n\nSave the data you want to use in a CSV file. Template","description":"Learn all about user management APIs and create one with ease using Postman’s free template.","keywords":"User management API"},"bannerHeader":"Endpoints for user registration, login, profile management, and more","faqHeader":"FAQs about the user management API prototype template"},"transactionId":null,"suggested":false,"recommended":false,"icon":"integration-testing-icon","collectionDescription":"# 👤 Get started here\n\nThis template demonstrates how to structure endpoints for a user management REST API that contains endpoints for user registration, login, profile management, and more.\n\nUsers created using this API can perform tasks like registering, logging in, and updating their profiles. Users who are assigned an 'admin' role can perform all tasks, including getting a list of all users and deleting user profiles.\n\n### 🔐 Authentication and authorization\n\nYou must have a valid bearer token to use the API added in this template. When you send the `Register` request, you will receive a token in the response. The `Register` request also contains a test script that sets the token in the `accessToken` collection variable so you can reuse it in other requests easily.\n\nTo send the requests in the `Admin` folder, you need to have admin permissions. You can grant yourself admin permissions using the `Register` request by adding a key named \"role\" with \"admin\" as the value in the request body.\n\n## 🔖 How to use this template?\n\n#### **Step 1: Send the requests**\n\nCheck out the different parts of the requests, including the request body, documentation, headers, tests, and path parameters. Send the requests to view the response returned.\n\nWe recommend you run the requests in this order to explore the different endpoints without running into any hiccups:\n\n`Register → Log in → Get profile → Update profile → Change user role → Get all users → Delete user`\n\n#### Step 2: Customize the requests\n\nUpdate the requests and examples to suit your use case, including the query parameters, authorization, documentation, headers, tests, and path parameters.\n\n#### **Step 3:** Continue building the collection\n\nCreate requests in this collection to test the new API endpoints you develop.\n\n#### **Step 4: Create a mock server**\n\nTo set up a mock server and build a functional prototype of your API:\n\n1. Select **Mock collection** from the collection's actions menu.\n2. On the **Create a mock server page** and add a name for your mock server.\n3. Complete the process by clicking **Create Mock Server**.\n4. Copy the mock URL generated. Select the collection template and navigate to the Variables tab. Update the `base_url` variable with your API's URL.\n5. Send the request! You should now see that the `base_url` variable is using the mock server you set up previously.\n6. Try editing fields in the mocked responses to see your changes reflected in the mock server.\n    \n\n## ℹ️ Resources\n\n[Building requests](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/requests/)  \n[Authorizing requests](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/authorization/)  \n[Using variables](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/variables/)  \n[Creating your first collection<br>](https://learning.postman.com/docs/getting-started/creating-the-first-collection/)[Configuring and using a Postman mock server](https://learning.postman.com/docs/designing-and-developing-your-api/mocking-data/setting-up-mock/)","categories":{"Use cases":["Prototyping"]}},{"id":"6f788c17-067a-4074-a528-d07df1df9529","name":"Integration testing #example","category":"Use Cases","illustration":"https://skills-assets.pstmn.io/collection-templates/integration-testing.gif","downloadCount":3856,"iconUrl":"https://skills-assets.pstmn.io/collection-templates/integration-testing-icon.svg","description":"Verify how different API endpoints, modules, and services interact with each other.","summary":[{"header":"Overview","description":"\"Integration testing helps you evaluate how well your API communicates and responds when connected to other modules or third-party services. <br><br> This example template includes test cases to ensure that various modules in the fictional Intergalactic Bank API function as expected when integrated. Use this template as a reference for creating and maintaining integration tests for your API.\"","target":["modal"]},{"header":"Recommended for","description":"","list":["Backend developers","QA engineers"],"target":["modal"]},{"header":"Contains","description":"\"Test cases and documentation for checking the integration of the Intergalactic Bank API with different modules and third-party services.\"","target":["modal"]},{"header":"Overview","description":"\"Integration testing helps you evaluate how well your API communicates and responds when connected to other modules or third-party services. <br><br> This example template includes test cases to ensure that various modules in the fictional Intergalactic Bank API function as expected when integrated. Use this template as a reference for creating and maintaining integration tests for your API.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What is integration testing?","description":"\"Integration testing is the process of testing multiple modules or components of an application together to ensure that they work harmoniously as a unified system. In the context of APIs, integration testing refers to the process of testing how different API endpoints, modules, or services interact with each other.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What does API integration testing involve?","description":"\"API integration testing involves testing the interaction and data exchange between different API endpoints and services. With API integration testing, you can validate that the APIs communicate correctly, produce accurate responses, and handle data flow consistently when integrated with other components of the application.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What does the integration testing template contain?","description":"\"The integration testing template contains test cases for verifying the integrations of the fictional Intergalactic Bank API with various modules and third-party services.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"How do you perform API integration testing with the template?","description":"\"Here are a few simple steps you can follow to test API integrations and ensure that various modules or services work together as expected:<br><br> **Step 1. Explore the template:** Read the documentation provided to learn more about the template and get the hang of setting up integration tests on Postman. <br><br> **Step 2. Execute sample tests:** Run the sample tests to verify the integration between different sample API endpoints and validate their interactions. <br><br> **Step 3. Create your integration tests** Update the existing collection or create a new one with requests and test scripts as per your API endpoints, data, and specific testing requirements.  <br><br> **Step 4. Set up a testing environment (optional):** Create an environment with the necessary configurations, such as authentication details and baseURL environment variables.  <br><br> **Step 5. Handle test failures:** In case of test failures, promptly investigate and address the root cause of the issues. Update the test cases as needed to reflect API changes or accommodate new requirements.\"","target":["landing page"]}],"faq":{"data":[{"key":"1","question":"What are the benefits of using the template?","answer":"The integration testing template serves as a guide for creating, organizing, and running integration tests in Postman. Here are two key benefits of using the template:\n\n- **Organized test cases:** The template provides a structured framework for organizing test cases, ensuring clarity and efficiency in test management. \n\n- **Efficient maintenance:** By providing a clear overview of test coverage and dependencies, the template demonstrates how to streamline the process of identifying and addressing gaps or changes in testing requirements."},{"key":"2","question":"API testing vs integration testing: What's the difference?","answer":"While the terms API testing and integration testing might be used interchangeably, these two tests are different.\n\nAPI testing focuses on verifying individual API endpoints' functionality and responses, ensuring each endpoint works as intended in isolation.\n\nOn the other hand, integration testing examines how different APIs interact and cooperate within the application's architecture, validating the integration points and data flow between components."}],"meta":{"faqHeader":"FAQs about the integration testing template"}},"relatedTemplates":["78475d97-9a36-4731-ab24-9adf6a94d0fb","7ab0f80e-a964-46ee-b948-4a4e3a85809c","3302192d-87dd-4612-b381-61894de21203","42247877-8529-429d-acba-4de20c3b5b3b"],"meta":{"pageMeta":{"title":"Integration Testing Template | Postman","description":"Learn how to test interactions between modules and APIs using Postman’s integration testing template.","keywords":"API integration testing, Integration testing template"},"bannerHeader":"Explore how to set up robust API integration tests on Postman"},"transactionId":null,"suggested":false,"recommended":false,"icon":"integration-testing-icon","collectionDescription":"> This collection identifies test cases to ensure that various Intergalactic Bank API modules function as expected with other modules within the API and also third-party services. Check out the [End-to-End](https://www.postman.com/templates/68de712c-6b56-4e31-8b0b-627360820279/End-to-end-testing) and [Functional](https://www.postman.com/templates/f26ad070-d626-4d75-b151-7cbf1a48ed11/Functional-testing) testing collection to see other test cases for this API. \n  \n\n## 🪐 Get started\n\nThe fictional Intergalactic Bank Services team is responsible for testing the integration workflows included in this collection. You can use this collection to validate specific workflows that your team relies on. Or suggest ways to increase test coverage and make your own applications more resilient.\n\nSteps to test the Intergalactic Bank API:\n\n1. **Review tests and scripts:** [Tests](https://learning.postman.com/docs/writing-scripts/test-scripts/) are written under the Scripts tab at the folder and request levels. Different testing requirements are distributed between the folders, so be sure to read the documentation for each folder to understand what is being tested.\n    \n2. **Run tests:** To run the collection, navigate to Run Collection from the collection menu. You can also elect to run only a folder if you are interested in testing a subset of the use cases. Be aware that many of these tests contain logic that passes information between requests, and they are meant to be run in order from top to bottom. If sending the requests manually or out of order, your results may vary.\n    \n3. **Review test results:** We have included error messages for many of the test cases to help debug what may be wrong with the service. If using this collection as a pre-merge check, be sure to have all tests passing before submitting (and no, deleting the failing test cases isn’t an option 😉).\n    \n\nFor more details, check out the additional sections below, and click `View Complete Documentation` for the complete documentation. If you have questions about the folder or request, look for the documentation icon for documentation-in-context.\n\n## ⚙️Integrating with third-party APIs\n\nYou will notice that we have two different APIs involved in this test collection: our Intergalactic Bank API that handles Accounts and Transactions, and the ATM locator API run by our partners.\n\n- **Differentiating these services:** Each service is represented by a different URL variable in the request: {{baseUrl}} for our Intergalactic Bank API, and {{atmLocatorUrl}} for the ATM locator service.\n    \n- **Production vs Mocks:** We are running these tests against the production service, but if you are setting up integration tests for the first time or have strict usage limits, consider swapping the production URL for a mock server.\n    \n- **Alert to changes:** We have this collection set up on a monitor to run every day. Since we have tests for all of the properties we use in our production systems, this will alert us if any breaking changes have been pushed to this API by our partners, so we can immediately remedy the situation.\n    \n\n## 🔒Authenticating multiple APIs\n\nNote that there are two different auth schemes for the two different APIs we are testing here. As the majority of the calls belong to the Intergalactic Bank API, we have set that authorization at the collection level, and have the relevant calls set to inherit this auth from the top level. For the ATM Locator API, we specify its specific API key at the request level.\n\n## 👀 View and share run results\n\nInterested in seeing previous run results? We’re happy to share, and have a few ways for you to stay in the loop:\n\n- You can also share individual run reports from this page.\n    \n- Monitors: If you have a monitor set up for this collection, you can see historical run information by clicking on the Monitors tab on the right sidebar. You can also have the results sent to Slack or other services by setting up an integration.\n    \n\n## 🤝Increase test coverage\n\nThe Intergalactic Bank Services team wants your team to have everything they need to successfully test our services with their applications. Is your team utilizing this API in a use case not represented here? Reach us on our internal Slack by tagging @bank-services. Or add an [inline comment](https://learning.postman.com/docs/collaborating-in-postman/working-with-your-team/discussing-your-work/) to this collection with your test case suggestions.","categories":{"Use cases":["Testing"],"Roles":["Quality Engineers"]}},{"id":"e1edbae8-6429-453d-890e-00385eea1811","name":"Common API vulnerabilities check","category":"Use case","illustration":"https://skills-assets.pstmn.io/collection-templates/common-API-vulnerabilities-checks.png","downloadCount":2152,"iconUrl":"https://skills-assets.pstmn.io/collection-templates/common-API-vulnerabilities-checks-icon.svg","description":"Check your API for common vulnerabilities and improve its security and reliability.","summary":[{"header":"Overview","description":"\"Conducting periodic API security checks can help you proactively identify threats and ensure that sensitive data is not compromised. With this template, you can check your API for common vulnerabilities like missing security headers and SQL injection.\""},{"header":"Recommended for","description":"\"\"","list":["Security Engineers","Backend Developers","Fullstack Developers"],"target":["modal"]},{"header":"Contains","description":"\"Pre-configured requests with test scripts that help you check for the following vulnerabilities:\"","list":["Cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) misconfiguration","Missing security headers","Authentication vulnerabilities","SQL injection"],"target":["modal"]},{"header":"What are some common API vulnerabilities?","description":"\"Here are a few common API vulnerabilities that can impact the security of an application: \\n\\n\\n- **Cross-Site Scripting (XSS):** XSS vulnerabilities occur when an attacker injects malicious scripts into an application, which unsuspecting users execute. \\n\\n\\n- **Injection Attacks:** Injection vulnerabilities, such as SQL injection or command injection, occur when untrusted user input is executed as part of a query or command, allowing attackers to manipulate the system. \\n\\n\\n- **Lack of Authentication and Authorization:** APIs that lack proper authentication and authorization mechanisms may allow unauthorized access to sensitive data or functionalities. \\n\\n\\n- **Insecure Direct Object References (IDOR):** IDOR vulnerabilities occur when an attacker can access or manipulate sensitive data or resources by directly referencing internal system objects. \\n\\n\\n- **Broken Access Control:** This vulnerability occurs when access control mechanisms are not properly implemented, allowing unauthorized users to perform actions they should not have access to. \\n\\n\\n- **Security Misconfigurations:** Misconfigurations in API servers, firewalls, or other components can expose sensitive information or open doors for attackers to exploit.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"How to defend against API vulnerabilities?","description":"\"To defend against API vulnerabilities, consider implementing the following best practices: \\n\\n\\n-**Input validation and sanitization:** Validate and sanitize all user input to prevent injection attacks and ensure that the API processes only expected and valid data. \\n\\n\\n- **Authentication and authorization:** Implement robust authentication mechanisms, such as OAuth or token-based authentication, and enforce proper authorization checks to control access to API resources. \\n\\n\\n- **Secure communication:** Use secure protocols, such as HTTPS/TLS, to encrypt communication between clients and the API server, protecting data in transit. \\n\\n\\n- **API rate limiting and throttling:** Implement rate limiting and throttling mechanisms to prevent abuse and protect against Denial-of-Service (DoS) attacks. \\n\\n\\n- **Error handling:** Implement appropriate error handling to prevent information leakage and ensure that error messages do not expose sensitive information. \\n\\n\\n- **Regular security audits and penetration testing:** Conduct regular security audits and penetration testing to identify vulnerabilities and weaknesses in your API, and address them proactively. \\n\\n\\n- **Keep software and libraries up to date:** Regularly update and patch your API's software dependencies and libraries to address known vulnerabilities and security issues. \\n\\n\\ By following these practices, you can significantly reduce the risk of API vulnerabilities and enhance the security of your application.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What does the common API vulnerabilities check template contain?","description":"\"The template contains pre-configured requests with test scripts that enable you to check your API for common vulnerabilities. It provides a set of tests and checks for various security vulnerabilities, including: \\n\\n\\n- Cross-origin resource sharing (CORS) misconfiguration \\n\\n\\n- Missing security headers \\n\\n\\n- Authentication vulnerabilities \\n\\n\\n- Directory traversal \\n\\n\\n- SQL injection \\n\\n\\n- Content injection \\n\\nWith this template, you can easily perform these checks on your API and identify potential vulnerabilities that may pose security risks.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"How to use the common API vulnerabilities check template?","description":"\"Step 1. Familiarize yourself with the template by going through the pre-configured requests with test scripts for each API vulnerability. <br><br>Step 2. Customize the template to suit your specific API endpoints, authentication mechanisms, or testing requirements. <br><br>Step 3. Execute the API checks by running the individual test scripts or requests against your API. <br><br>Step 4. After running the tests, review the results and identify any vulnerabilities that the template flags. <br><br>Step 5. Consider adding additional checks or tests to the template based on unique security considerations for your API.\"","target":["landing page"]}],"faq":{"data":[{"key":"1","question":"Who can use the template?","answer":"The Common API Vulnerabilities Check template can be used by developers, security professionals, and anyone responsible for API security to assess and mitigate common vulnerabilities in their APIs."},{"key":"2","question":"What are the benefits of using this template?","answer":"Using this template helps you proactively identify and address common API vulnerabilities, enhancing the security and reliability of your APIs. It provides a structured approach to security testing and offers pre-configured checks for common security weaknesses."}]},"relatedTemplates":[],"meta":{"pageMeta":{"title":"Common API Vulnerabilities & How To Identify Them","description":"Learn about common API vulnerabilities and how to identify them in a few simple steps.","keywords":"api vulnerability"},"bannerHeader":"Improve API security by proactively identifying API vulnerabilities"},"transactionId":null,"suggested":false,"recommended":false,"icon":"integration-testing-icon","collectionDescription":"# 🛡️Get started here\n\nThis template helps you check your APIs for the following things:\n\n###### Security vulnerabilities\n\n- [CORS Misconfigurations](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/CORS)\n- [SQL Injection](https://portswigger.net/web-security/sql-injection)\n- [Authentication](https://portswigger.net/web-security/authentication)\n    \n\n###### Security headers\n\n- [Content-Security-Policy](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Content-Security-Policy)\n- [X-Frame-Options](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/X-Frame-Options)\n- [Strict-Transport-Security](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Strict-Transport-Security)\n- [X-XSS-Protection](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/X-XSS-Protection)\n    \n\n###### [Content Secure Policy](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/CSP)\n\n## 🔖 How to use this template\n\n**Step 1:** Define the following collection variables.\n\n| **Collection variable** | **Value** |\n| --- | --- |\n| `base_url` | API base URL that you want to test |\n| `malicious_origin` | Suspicious or Foreign Origin that you want to test your API for |\n| `sub_domain_url` | An unauthorized subdomain URL |\n| `access_token_key` | Key name that contains the access token (default value is `x-access-token`) |\n| `valid_access_token_value` | Valid access token to access the API |\n| `expired_access_token_value` | Expired access token |\n| `other_user_access_token_value` | Other User's valid access token |\n| `param_key` | The key that is used to send the user ID or name |\n| `param_value` | The value for the key mentioned in the `param_key` variable |\n\n**Step 2:** Once configured, run the collection within the `Runner`.\n\n**Step 3:** View the test results. Failed tests could mean that the API is vulnerable to an attack. demonstrating the core features of a news REST API, like fetching, creating, updating and deleting news articles. You can use this template as inspiration to build your custom API or extend it to work with one you've already started working on.\n\n## 🔖 How to use this template?\n\nHere’s the order of steps in which you can explore this template to understand it better:\n\n#### **Step 1: Send the requests**\n\nSend the requests and view the response returned. Each request has an example response saved that you can use as a reference for your API prototype.\n\nWe recommend you run the requests in this order to explore the different endpoints without running into any hiccups:\n\n`Create news → Get news by ID → Get all news → Get related news → Update news → Get top headlines → Get all sources → Filter news → Delete event`\n\n#### Step 2: Customize the requests\n\nUpdate the requests and examples to suit your use case, including the query parameters, authorization, documentation, headers, tests, and path parameters.\n\n#### **Step 3:** Continue building the collection\n\nCreate requests in this collection to test the new API endpoints you develop.\n\n#### **Step 4: Create a mock server**\n\nTo set up a mock server and build a functional prototype of your API:\n\n1. Select **Mock collection** from the collection's actions menu.\n    \n2. On the **Create a mock server page** and add a name for your mock server.\n    \n3. Complete the process by clicking **Create Mock Server**.\n    \n4. Copy the mock URL generated. Select the collection template and navigate to the Variables tab. are popular examples of file storage APIs catering to different use cases and business needs:\n\n* **Amazon Simple Storage Service (Amazon S3):** A scalable and highly available object storage service by Amazon Web Services (AWS) that allows users to store and retrieve any amount of data.\n\n* **Google Cloud Storage:** A secure, durable, and scalable cloud object storage service provided by Google Cloud Platform.\n\n* **Dropbox API:** Allows developers to integrate Dropbox into their applications, enabling users to access and manage files stored in their Dropbox accounts.\n\n* **Microsoft OneDrive API:** Enables developers to integrate Microsoft OneDrive into their applications, allowing users to store, access, and share files."}]},"relatedTemplates":["47b316dc-6766-404f-a58a-4592bf47dac2","da8172d0-679b-4173-9104-0ecef2c32cd3","6c949b0d-3247-4de1-a0db-278d59e3d777","25475070-e224-4d3d-b04a-8830b6c6bd69"],"meta":{"pageMeta":{"title":"Prototype Using this template, you can create snapshots, test your API responses against them, and fish out any unexpected responses.\""},{"header":"Recommended for","description":"","list":["Quality Engineers","Backend Developers","Fullstack Developers","Frontend Developers"],"target":["modal"]},{"header":"Contains","description":"\"A sample request and test scripts for the following three snapshot testing strategies:\"","list":["The response should have the snapshot as its subset.","The response should match the snapshot.","The response should match the JSON Schema generated from the snapshot."],"target":["modal"]},{"header":"What is snapshot testing?","description":"\"Snapshot testing is a technique in API development that involves capturing the current state of API responses (snapshots) and then comparing subsequent API responses against these snapshots. It helps ensure that the API responses remain consistent over time and that no unexpected changes occur.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What are the benefits of snapshot testing?","description":"\"Here are three main advantages of performing snapshot testing: \\n\\n\\n- **Ensuring consistency:** Snapshot testing helps maintain the consistency of API responses, reducing the likelihood of introducing bugs or errors during development. \\n\\n\\n- **Simplified test maintenance:** Since snapshots serve as a reference, they simplify the process of updating and maintaining tests when the API responses change intentionally. \\n\\n\\n- **Time efficiency:** Snapshot testing significantly reduces the time spent manually verifying API responses and improves the overall testing efficiency.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What does the response snapshot testing template contain?","description":"\"The response snapshot testing template contains sample API requests and reusable test scripts that demonstrate the following three snapshot testing strategies: \\n\\n\\n- **Snapshot subset:** Verifying that the API response contains a subset of the snapshot, ensuring that any additional data is acceptable. \\n\\n\\n- **Exact snapshot match:** Ensuring the API response matches the exact snapshot, detecting any unexpected changes. \\n\\n\\n- **JSON schema comparison:** Matching the API response against the JSON Schema generated from the snapshot, validating response structure and data types.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"How to use the template to perform snapshot testing?","description":"\"By following the steps listed below, you can effectively perform snapshot testing using the template -  <br><br>**Step 1. Understand the template:** Familiarize yourself with the contents and purpose of the template. Read the documentation to interact with the template and get the hang of snapshot testing in Postman. <br><br>**Step 2. Customize the template:** Customize the pre-configured requests to match your API's endpoints and specific testing requirements. Capture snapshots of the initial API responses by saving your response as an example in Postman. <br><br>**Step 3. Prepare for testing:** Create a mock server to help with snapshot testing. Update the 'snapshotURL' variable in the collection with your mock server's URL. <br><br>**Step 4. Choose a snapshot strategy:** Decide how you want to perform the snapshot testing based on your response structure. <br><br>**Step 5. Run the tests**: Resend the request and check the test results in the response section's 'Test Results' tab.\"","target":["landing page"]}],"faq":{"data":[{"key":"1","question":"Who can use the template?","answer":"The response snapshot testing template can be used by anyone who is involved in API development, including: \n\n- Quality engineers \n\n- Backend developers \n\n- Fullstack developers \n\n- Frontend developers"},{"key":"2","question":"When should you perform snapshot testing?","answer":"Snapshot testing is a testing technique used primarily in frontend development, especially for UI components and visual elements. Here are a few scenarios in which you can perform snapshot testing: \n\n When developing UI components (e.g., React components, Vue components), snapshot testing can ensure that changes to the component's output don't introduce unexpected visual regressions. \n When you refactor or change your codebase, snapshot testing can ensure that the visual output remains consistent. \n\nIt's important to note that snapshot testing is not a replacement for unit or end-to-end testing. Instead, it complements these other testing strategies, providing an additional layer of confidence in the visual aspects of your application."}]},"relatedTemplates":[],"meta":{"pageMeta":{"title":"Response Snapshot Testing | Postman","description":"Learn what snapshot testing is and how to conduct it. This type of testing ensures that your API response adheres to the originally accepted structure/value of your response.\n\nThis template contains test scripts for the following three snapshot testing strategies:\n\n- Response should have the snapshot as its subset _(selected by default)._\n    \n- Response should match the snapshot.\n    \n- Response should match the JSON Schema generated from the snapshot.\n    \n\n## 🔖 **How to use this template**\n\n**Step 1:** Create a new request in this collection with the API you want to run a snapshot test for.\n\n**Step 2:** Send your request and save the response as an example. In the \"Scripts\" tab of this collection, simply replace `pm.skip` with `pm.test` for your selected strategy.\n\n**Step 6:** Send your request again and check if your tests passed by heading to the \"Test Results\" tab in the response section.\n\n## ℹ️ Resources\n\n[Snapshot testing using Postman](https://quickstarts.postman.com/guide/snapshot-testing/index.html)  \n[Setting up mock servers](https://learning.postman.com/docs/designing-and-developing-your-api/mocking-data/setting-up-mock/)  \n[Using variables](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/variables/)","categories":{"Use cases":["Testing"],"Roles":["Quality Engineers"]}},{"id":"15fcb4d8-d3df-48c7-bd10-04fd484efb0f","name":"Write responses to file","category":"Use case","illustration":"https://skills-assets.pstmn.io/collection-templates/write-responses-to-file.png","downloadCount":1493,"iconUrl":"https://skills-assets.pstmn.io/collection-templates/write-responses-to-file-icon.svg","description":"Automate the process of capturing API responses and storing them in a local file.","summary":[{"header":"Overview","description":"\"Storing API responses in a local file can help you log responses and quickly analyze and process the response data. By using the template, you can log and store API responses for further analysis, processing, or documentation.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What does the write responses to file template contain?","description":"\"The template contains a sample request and a reusable script that enables you to write API responses to a file. You can tailor it to your unique data requirements."}],"meta":{"faqHeader":"FAQs about the write responses to file template"}},"relatedTemplates":[],"meta":{"pageMeta":{"title":"How to Write Responses to File | Postman","description":"Automate the process of capturing API responses and storing them in a local file.","keywords":"postman save response to file, postman write to file, postman runner save response to file"},"bannerHeader":"Start writing responses to a local file in a few seconds","cta":"Use Template"},"transactionId":null,"suggested":false,"recommended":false,"icon":"integration-testing-icon","collectionDescription":"# 📑 Get started here\n\nThis collection makes it easy for users who want to write the response of each request to a file. This can be extended to write anything for eg. meta information or value of variables being used.\n\nTo work with this script, a local server is required. You can choose to write your own local server or edit the one provided below as per your needs.\n\n## 🔖 How to use this template?\n\n#### Step 1: Collate all requests\n\nPut all the requests you want to write the responses for, under this collection.\n\n#### Step 2: Run this script and start the local server\n\nCopy the script below and run it in your terminal, this will spawn a local server written on python responsible for saving the file.\n\n``` bash\npython3 -c \"\nimport os\nimport json\nfrom http.server import BaseHTTPRequestHandler, HTTPServer\nfrom time import time\nclass FileUploadHandler(BaseHTTPRequestHandler):\n    def do_POST(self):\n        content_type = self.headers.get('Content-Type', 'application/json')\n        content_length = int(self.headers.get('Content-Length', 0))\n        post_data = self.rfile.read(content_length)\n        if content_type == 'application/json':\n            post_data = json.loads(post_data)\n            file_extension = post_data.get('fileExtension', content_type.split('/')[1])\n            file_name = post_data.get('fileName',  'temp-' +  str(time()) + '.' + file_extension)\n            file_path = os.path.join(os.getcwd(), file_name)\n            with open(file_path, 'w') as f:\n                if file_extension == 'json':\n                  json.dump(json.loads(post_data.get('responseData')), f)\n                else:\n                  f.write(post_data)\n        else:\n          file_extension = content_type.split('/')[1]\n          file_name = 'temp-' +  str(time()) + '.' + file_extension\n          file_path = os.path.join(os.getcwd(), file_name)\n          with open(file_path, 'wb') as f:\n              f.write(post_data)\n        self.send_response(200)\n        self.send_header('Content-type','application/json')\n        self.end_headers()\n        self.wfile.write(bytes(json.dumps({'filePath': file_path}), 'utf8'))\nif __name__ == '__main__':\n    with HTTPServer(('', 3000), FileUploadHandler) as server:\n      print('Starting HTTP server...')\n      server.serve_forever()\n\"\n\n```\n\n#### Step 3: Customize the requests\n\n1. The responses for every request which is a part of this collection will be written to the path from where the above script is executed. You can modify the local server's running path to change the file location.\n2. Run your requests through builder or you can also run through collection runner and store your data locally.\n    \n\n#### Step 4: Continue building the collection\n\nContinue building the collection by creating additional API endpoints to test their new functionality.\n\n## Additionally\n\nInstead of moving each request under this collection, you can copy the script from the Tests tab of this collection to the Tests tab of any request or even a specific folder.\n\nNote: To access the Tests script of this collection, you need to click the `Write responses To file` collection in the sidebar. and go to the Tests tab.\n\nThen you can send that particular request / requests under a folder for which the data needs to be written.\n\n## ℹ️ Resources\n\n[Sending Request](https://www.getpostman.com/docs/v6/postman/scripts/postman_sandbox_api_reference#pmsendrequest)  \n[Authorizing requests](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/authorization/)  \n[Using variables](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/variables/)  \n[Creating your first collection](https://learning.postman.com/docs/getting-started/creating-the-first-collection/)","categories":{"Postman essentials":["Workflow optimization"]}},{"id":"9888b1e1-381e-47df-bb3f-8794dd0f2337","name":"OpenAI: Completion and generation","category":"Industry","illustration":"https://skills-assets.pstmn.io/collection-templates/open-AI.gif","downloadCount":1253,"iconUrl":"https://skills-assets.pstmn.io/collection-templates/open-AI-icon.svg","description":"Interact with OpenAI API endpoints for processing or generating text, images, audio, and files.","summary":[{"header":"Overview","description":"\"You can use the OpenAI API to develop anything that involves processing or generating text or code, from chatbots to image recognition applications. It also simplifies maintenance and updates."},{"key":"2","question":"Can I use this template for both manual and automated testing?","answer":"Yes, you can apply the principles and examples provided in this template to both manual and automated testing in Postman. It's useful for testers and developers alike."},{"key":"3","question":"Are there best practices for naming and organizing reusable requests and scripts?","answer":"It's a good practice to use descriptive names and create a logical folder structure to organize your reusable requests and scripts for easy reference and identification."}],"meta":{"faqHeader":"FAQs about the reusing requests and scripts template"}},"relatedTemplates":[],"meta":{"pageMeta":{"title":"Reusing requests and scripts in Postman","description":"Check out how to reuse requests and scripts in multiple collections. Use the scripts given in this template to speed up this task.","keywords":"Reusing requests"},"bannerHeader":"Reuse requests and scripts in three simple steps"},"transactionId":null,"suggested":false,"recommended":false,"icon":"integration-testing-icon","collectionDescription":"# 🔁 Get started here\n\nThis template demonstrates how a request or a script from a collection can be reused/referenced in a different collection. It contains examples for reusing a request, pre-request script, and post-response script.\n\nThis idea can also be extended to create a repository of scripts and reuse them across different collections.\n\n**NOTE:** The only caveat with this approach is that you will have to make an extra API call to fetch a request/script that you want to reuse.\n\n## 🔖 **How to use this template**\n\n#### Step 1: **Add API key**\n\nAdd your [API Key](https://learning.postman.com/docs/developer/postman-api/authentication/#generate-a-postman-api-key) in the `Variables` tab of the collection. You can access your API key [here](http://go.postman.co/settings/me/api-keys).\n\n#### Step 2: **Customize the script**\n\nWe have added the following script in the sample requests. Feel free to customize it to your needs. You can also add your API base URL to the `base_url` collection variable.\n\n```\neval(pm.variables.get(\"executeReferencedRequest\"));\nexecuteReferencedRequest({\n    collectionUId: \"<COLLECTION_UID>\",\n    requestUId: \"<REQUEST_UID>\", // can also use requestName instead\n    apiKey: pm.variables.get(\"apiKey\")\n}, () => {\n    eval(pm.variables.get(\"referencedPreRequestScript\"));\n    pm.request.update(pm.variables.get(\"referencedRequest\"));\n    eval(pm.variables.get(\"referencedTestScript\"));\n});\n\n ```\n\n#### Step 3: **Add relevant collection and request ID**\n\nAdd `collectionUId` and `requestUId` in the above script. Here `collectionUId` is the UID of the collection from which you want to reference the request, and `requestUId` is the UID of the request you want to reuse/reference. These can be copied from the right sidebar by clicking on ⓘ the icon of a collection or a request, respectively.\n\n#### Step 4: **Use the local variables**\n\nWe have added `executeReferencedRequest` in these three local variables:\n\n- `referencedPreRequestScript` - Contains the pre-request script of the referenced request.\n    \n- `referencedTestScript` - Contains the post-response script of the referenced request.\n    \n- `referencedRequest` - Contains the actual referenced request.\n    \n\nYou can use any of these based on your use case.\n\n### ℹ️ Resources\n\nPlease refer to this [Gist](https://gist.github.com/prashantagarwal/f278b3ca78b3927cde06f68674b82cae) on GitHub.","categories":{"Postman essentials":["Workflow optimization"]}},{"id":"a4cfd823-8d6b-47bc-8582-4df726193875","name":"Amazon Web Services (AWS) infrastructure","category":"Use case","illustration":"https://skills-assets.pstmn.io/collection-templates/aws.png","downloadCount":732,"iconUrl":"https://skills-assets.pstmn.io/collection-templates/aws-icon.svg","description":"Manage Cloud instances and storage using the AWS API.","summary":[{"header":"Overview","description":"\"This template helps you easily interact with Amazon Simple Storage Service and Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud API endpoints. These practices include: \n\n- Maintain consistency in formatting and terminology to provide a cohesive user experience. \n\n- Provide clear and concise descriptions for each endpoint to facilitate understanding and usage. \n\n- Ensure thorough documentation of parameters and headers to help your teammates successfully use your API requests. \n\n- Offer relevant examples and sample responses to illustrate expected behaviors and outcomes. \n\n- Regularly update the documentation to reflect changes or enhancements to the APIs, keeping it accurate and relevant."}],"meta":{"faqHeader":"FAQs about the blueprint documentation template"}},"relatedTemplates":["f4c82697-26eb-4feb-9d88-61dbae7d65b0","53736124-ad4d-4cc9-a57a-f7e83402fbe7","e9c28f47-1253-44af-a2f3-20dce4da1f18"],"meta":{"pageMeta":{"title":"Blueprint Documentation Template: Streamline Internal API Onboarding","description":"Discover how blueprint documentation accelerates API onboarding for frontend developers, QA engineers, and other internal consumers.","keywords":"Blueprint documentation template"},"bannerHeader":"Learn how to create the best documentation for your internal API consumers"},"transactionId":null,"suggested":false,"recommended":false,"icon":"integration-testing-icon","collectionDescription":"> Blueprint Documentation helps internal consumers onboard to your APIs quickly. This example Template contains a list of executable endpoints that internal API consumers from the fictional Intergalactic Bank can leverage, so they can easily select the ones that best suit their needs. \n  \n\n### **Table of contents:**\n\n> **🧪** What can I do with this API?  \n🪐 Get Started  \n🔐 Authorization  \n⏱ Rate and usage limits  \n✍️ Example Responses  \n🤔 Need Help? \n  \n\n## **🧪 What can I do with this API?**\n\nBrowse potential endpoints to suit the needs of internal API consumers, and build your own new workflows. Common workflows can be found here, such as:\n\n- How many users created an account in the last week?\n    \n- What is the most common currency in use across accounts?\n    \n\nLook for requests with visualizations to evaluate response data quickly.\n\n<img src=\"https://content.pstmn.io/0ffa216d-e983-4bbe-ae94-4aa2c05fb3b6/RGF0YS5naWY=\">\n\n## **🪐 Get Started**\n\nSteps to get started with the Intergalactic Bank API:\n\n1. **Authorization**: Use a valid API Key to send requests to the API endpoints. For this API, everyone will use a temporary API key (prefilled as a collection variable).\n    \n2. **Access**: If you need elevated access to perform actions like creating new accounts, contact the Intergalactic Bank API product owner.\n    \n\n> Some endpoints are for Admin Users only. These are noted in the request's documentation. \n  \n\nFor more details, check out the additional sections below, and click `View Complete Documentation` for an expanded view of the complete documentation. If you have questions about a specific folder or request, look for the documentation icon for documentation-in-context.\n\n## **🔐 Authorization**\n\n- The Intergalactic Bank API uses an API Key for authorization.\n    \n- You must include an API key in each request to the Postman API with the `x-api-key` request header.\n    \n- The API key has been pre-filled as a [collection variable](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/variables/). The authorization has been set up at the collection level, so all requests in this collection will automatically inherit the needed header.\n    \n\n> ⚠ Don’t leak your secrets! Initial values are saved, and can be shared with others in team workspaces. Current values are local values that are not saved, and won't be persisted in the original shared collection, environment, or globals. [Learn more about variables in Postman](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EKv6n-jY9lU&list=PLM-7VG-sgbtC5tNXxd28cmePSa9BYwqeU&index=65) \n  \n\n<img src=\"https://content.pstmn.io/14d5db15-297f-45fd-a5d4-48d56b7a8306/Qmx1ZXByaW50LmdpZg==\">\n\n## Rate and usage limits\n\nAPI access rate limits apply at a per-API key basis in unit time. The limit is 300 requests per minute.\n\nIf you exceed either limit, your request will return an HTTP `429 Too Many Requests` status code. If your team is consistently hitting these limits, contact the Intergalactic API Product Owner, and we will work to accommodate you.\n\nEach API response returns the following set of headers to help you identify your use status:\n\n| Header | Description |\n| --- | --- |\n| `X-RateLimit-Limit` | The maximum number of requests that the consumer is permitted to make per minute. |\n| `X-RateLimit-Remaining` | The number of requests remaining in the current rate limit window. |\n| `X-RateLimit-Reset` | The time at which the current rate limit window resets in UTC epoch seconds. |\n\n## ✍️ Example Responses\n\nWe have documented many of the possible responses you might encounter using [Examples](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/examples/) under each request.\n\n### 🤔 Need Help?\n\nThe Bank Services team wants to ensure that your team has everything they need to successfully integrate our services into your applications and services. Don't hesitate to reach out to us on our internal Slack by tagging `@bank-services`\n\n> Is your team utilizing this API in a use case not represented here? We want to know about it! This template guides you through building and running requests in an async manner to ensure tasks are processed predictably and enhance your app’s performance.\"","target":["landing page","modal"]},{"header":"Recommended for","description":"","list":["Backend Developers","Fullstack Developers","Frontend Developers","Quality Engineers"],"target":["modal"]},{"header":"Contains","description":"\"Sample requests that demonstrate how to set up async operations using the following functions:\"","list":["async.series (sequential asynchronous execution)","async.parallel (concurrent asynchronous execution)","async.race (asynchronous race condition)","async.waterfall (chained asynchronous execution)"],"target":["modal"]},{"header":"What are asynchronous operations?","description":"\"Asynchronous operations, or async operations, help you execute requests and handle responses independently of the main program or flow. You can use asynchronous operations to handle tasks like uploading multiple files to a server, web scraping, and updating shared resources. In the context of API development, asynchronous operations allow you to handle requests and responses concurrently without blocking the execution of other tasks. This asynchronous approach helps you enhance the performance and responsiveness of your application.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What does the asynchronous operations template contain?","description":"\"The asynchronous operations template contains sample requests and functions that demonstrate how to set up and execute asynchronous operations in Postman. These examples showcase how to handle asynchronous tasks in your API workflow, allowing you to optimize the processing of requests and responses. The template includes the following functions - \\n\\n- async.series (sequential asynchronous execution) \\n\\n\\n- async.parallel (concurrent asynchronous execution) \\n\\n\\n- async.race (asynchronous race condition) \\n\\n\\n- async.waterfall (chained asynchronous execution)\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"How to use the asynchronous operations template?","description":"\"Follow these easy steps to use the asynchronous operations template effectively: <br><br>**Step 1. Explore the sample requests and functions:** Go through the examples and understand how the functions are utilized to perform asynchronous operations.<br><br>**Step 2. Customize the template:** Modify the sample requests and functions to match your API endpoints and desired asynchronous patterns. Update the request configurations, URLs, headers, and function logic as needed.<br><br>**Step 3. Execute the asynchronous operations:** Send the requests and observe how the asynchronous operations are handled. Analyze the results, especially the order and timing of execution.<br><br>**Step 4. Incorporate into your workflow:** Based on your requirements, implement relevant asynchronous patterns given in the template. Integrate them into your existing workflows or use them as a reference to set up asynchronous operations in your API development.\"","target":["landing page"]}],"faq":{"data":[{"key":"1","question":"Who can use the template?","answer":"The asynchronous operations template is suitable for various roles involved in API development, including Backend Developers, Fullstack Developers, Frontend Developers, and Quality Engineers. Anyone seeking to optimize the performance and responsiveness of their API applications can benefit from using this template."},{"key":"2","question":"What are some applications of asynchronous operations?","answer":"Here are a few common applications of asynchronous operations: \n\n- **File input/output:** Reading from or writing to files asynchronously. \n\n- **Network operations:** Performing network requests, such as HTTP requests or socket communication asynchronously. \n\n- **Database operations:** Executing database queries or transactions asynchronously. \n\n- **Timers and delays:** Setting up timers or scheduling tasks to be executed after a specific delay or at a specific time. \n\n- **Event handling:** Processing user interactions, system events, or message passing between components asynchronously. \n\n- **Parallel processing:** Executing computationally intensive tasks in parallel by utilizing multiple CPU cores or distributed systems. \n\n- **Task queues:** Managing and processing tasks asynchronously from a queue, ensuring efficient utilization of resources and workload distribution. \n\n- **Asynchronous messaging:** Sending or receiving messages between components or systems to enable asynchronous communication and decoupling. \n\n- **Asynchronous streaming:** Processing continuous streams of data asynchronously, such as real-time data feeds or audio/video streaming. \n\n- **Asynchronous task completion:** Waiting for one or more tasks to complete and handling the results asynchronously."}],"meta":{"faqHeader":"FAQs about the asynchronous operations template"}},"relatedTemplates":[],"meta":{"pageMeta":{"title":"Asynchronous Operations Template | Postman","description":"What are asynchronous operations? Replicate, Stable diffusion, and OpenAI API endpoints for performing the following image-based tasks -\n\n- **Text-to-image:** Generating images from text using text-to-image models\n- **Image-to-image:** Generating upscaled, variations, edits of an image using image-to-image models\n- **Image-to-text:** Generating textual content, such as a caption from an image, using image-to-text models\n- **Image restoration:** Restoring old images using image restoration models\n- **Object detection:** Detecting and locating objects in an image using object detection models\n- **Diffusion:** Using diffusion models for image generation\n- **Models**: Fetching details of the models available\n    \n\n## 🔖 How to use this template?\n\n> Note: You must have a valid API token/key to get access to the AI models and run the requests successfully. \n  \n\n#### Step 1: Creating and adding API keys\n\n1. **OpenAI**: On the [API Keys page of the OpenAI website](https://platform.openai.com/account/api-keys), create a new API key under API Keys -> `+ Create new secret key`.\n    \n\n<img src=\"https://content.pstmn.io/8e510369-7ed3-418c-b451-b732d865d3ea/T3BlbkFJIGtleS5wbmc=\" width=\"602\" height=\"422\">\n\n2\\. **Replicate**: On the [API tokens page of the Replicate website](https://replicate.com/account/api-tokens), create a new API token under API Tokens -> `New User API Token`.\n\n<img src=\"https://content.pstmn.io/fddf8d51-68a9-4da5-bf23-9ca5a2167b8a/aW1hZ2UucG5n\" width=\"560\" height=\"286\">\n\n3\\. **Stable diffusion:** On the [API keys page of the Stable diffusion website](https://stablediffusionapi.com/settings/api), create a new API key.\n\n<img src=\"https://content.pstmn.io/d3a12c94-a3ec-43c6-a1f3-cd764017617c/aW1hZ2UucG5n\" width=\"548\" height=\"246\">\n\n4\\. Add your API tokens/keys in the `replicate_token` , `open_ai_token`, and `stable_diffusion_token` collection variables respectively and send requests. If you're on a free account, be careful about the number of times you hit **Send** since you might exhaust your free credits.\n\n<img src=\"https://content.pstmn.io/847542e8-2ec3-4304-9c53-b4026f0c1f0a/aW1hZ2UucG5n\" width=\"602\" height=\"231\">\n\n#### **Step 2: Send the requests**\n\nSend the requests and view the response returned by the APIs, or check out the examples included.\n\n**Working with Replicate API:**\n\n> Note: Replicate models work in an asynchronous manner, i.e. every time you send a request to run a model, you're creating something called as a prediction with a unique prediction ID. A prediction is an object that holds the outputs that the model returned, as well as other metadata such as the status of the request. To fetch the results you need to use the prediction ID in a separate GET request that is provided in the folder. For the given examples, this is done automattically using a script a script in the Tests tab. \n  \n\nLet's look at an example for converting text to image using the Stable diffusion model:\n\n1. Run the `Trigger prediction using Stable diffusion model` request after updating the body of the request with your desired input. This will create a prediction and return the prediction ID, along with other details regarding the request.\n2. Run the `Get generated image from prediction` request after ensuring that the prediction ID in the `predictionId` path variable points to the ID provided in the previous request's response.\n3. If the prediction is completed, you will receive a response with status as `succeeded`, having the response from the model in the `output` property. Some predictions can take a few seconds to generate, so you need to keep poling i.e. keep fetching the response until completion.\n    \n\n**Working with Open API and Stable diffusion API:**\n\n> Note: OpenAI and Stable diffusion models are straight-forward since they are synchrounous, i.e. you just need to send a request to a model and it will to send a response back to you once the processing is completed. \n  \n\nLet's look at an example for converting text to image using the Dall-E model provided by the OpenAI API:\n\n1. Run the `Generate image using Dall-E model` request after updating the request body with your desired input.\n2. The model will return a response after it has finished processing, you can fetch the output from the `output` property in the response object.\n    \n\n#### **3: Customize the requests**\n\nUpdate the requests to suit your use case, including the request body, authorization, documentation, headers, tests, and path parameters.\n\n## ℹ️ Resources\n\n[How does replicate work?](https://replicate.com/docs/how-does-replicate-work)  \n[OpenAI API documentation](https://platform.openai.com/docs/introduction)  \n[Stable diffusion API documentation](https://stablediffusionapi.com/docs/)  \n[Replicate HTTP API documentation](https://replicate.com/docs/reference/http)  \n[Authorizing requests](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/authorization/)  \n[Using variables](https://learning.postman.com/docs/sending-requests/variables/)  \n[Creating your first collection](https://learning.postman.com/docs/getting-started/creating-the-first-collection/)","categories":{}},{"id":"26dd30aa-83f6-4eec-8abe-2dc4461637b4","name":"AI text toolkit","category":"Industry","illustration":"https://skills-assets.pstmn.io/collection-templates/AI-text-toolkit.png","downloadCount":147,"iconUrl":"https://skills-assets.pstmn.io/collection-templates/AI-text-toolkit-icon.svg","description":"Perform various text-based tasks using endpoints from the OpenAI API.","summary":[{"header":"Overview","description":"\"This template contains OpenAI API endpoints that help with tasks like text generation, completion, translation, summarization, sentiment analysis, and content moderation.
