API keys such as Postman API keys, Slack tokens, or Stripe API keys, can be accidentally shared in messages and pose a security risk. The scanner scans through Slack messages and detects patterns or keywords associated with these secret keys, helping organizations identify and address potential security vulnerabilities.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"What are the benefits of using a Slack API secret key scanner?","description":"\"By using a Slack API secret key scanner, organizations can improve their security posture, minimize the risk of unauthorized access, and ensure the protection of sensitive data. Here’s a closer look at the benefits:\\n\\n\\n- **Enhanced security:** The scanner helps identify any leaked or exposed API keys in Slack messages, allowing organizations to take prompt action to mitigate potential security threats.\\n\\n\\n- **Automation and efficiency:** The scanner eliminates the need for manual searching and monitoring, ensuring a more efficient and thorough scanning process.\\n\\n\\n- **Proactive detection:** By implementing scheduled scans, organizations can identify any newly shared secret keys and promptly address them before they can be exploited by malicious actors.\\n\\n\\n- **Compliance and regulatory requirements:** Many industries and jurisdictions have strict data protection regulations and compliance requirements. Utilizing a Slack API secret key scanner helps organizations meet these requirements by actively monitoring and preventing the exposure of sensitive information.\\n\\n\\n- **Reporting and resolution:** The scanner generates reports that highlight the identified secret keys and their associated messages. This enables organizations to quickly investigate and resolve any security issues, ensuring a proactive and efficient response.\"","target":["landing page"]},{"header":"How to use the Slack API key scanner template?","description":"\"**Step 1. It also enables you to compile this information into a report and send that to a Slack channel.\n\n## 🔖 How to use this template?\n\n#### Step 1: Create Slack app\n\nCreate a new Slack app ([https://api.slack.com/apps](https://api.slack.com/apps)).\n\n#### Step 2: Go to OAuth & Permissions tab\n\nGo to _the OAuth & Permissions_ tab of the newly created Slack app and add the following scopes in `Bot Token Scopes`:\n\n`channels:history`, `channels:join`, `channels:read`, `chat:write`, `groups:history`, `groups:read`, `im:history`, `mpim:history`, `mpim:read`\n\n#### Step 3: Install the app and add token\n\nClick on \"Install the App to your workspace\" and copy the generated `Bot User OAuth Token`.\n\n#### Step 4: Set the token in the collection\n\nSet copied token in the `BotOAuthToken` and `SlackUserKey` collection variables.\n\n#### Step 5: Add Slack channel\n\nAdd the ID of the Slack channel where you want to send the information about the leaked secrets in the `notificationChannel` environment variable.\n\n#### Step 6: Send the requests\n\nSend the requests and view the response returned by the API, or check out the examples included.\n\n#### Step 7: Customize the requests\n\nUpdate the different parts of the requests to suit your use case, including the request body, authorization, documentation, headers, tests, and path parameters.\n\n#### Step 8: Add a monitor\n\nNow configure the Postman Monitor to run this collection periodically, or you can run the collection manually using Collection Runner or Newman. [Learn how to create a Postman Monitor](https://learning.postman.com/docs/designing-and-developing-your-api/monitoring-your-api/setting-up-monitor/).\n\n## Results\n\nYou'll receive a Slack message containing leaked sensitive credentials in the Slack workspace at the end of each monitor or collection run.\n\n<img src=\"https://64.media.tumblr.com/bb7c33863c8c058517a8df5548ecb973/ae6decf83d619849-14/s2048x3072/b0210d7ea79647dd3622e9e28e1dd9c5943b17a2.png\" alt=\"Notification%20Example\">\n\n## Supported secrets / API keys\n\nThis collection scans for the following secrets.
